prompt: Can you help me brainstorm a list of places to take guests visiting Santa Fe from out of town that aren’t reliant on good weather? My guests were planning to come and do lots of hiking in nature, but the forecast now says it will be raining most of the time they’re here.

messages.content: Can you help me brainstorm a list of places to take guests visiting Santa Fe from out of town that aren’t reliant on good weather? My guests were planning to come and do lots of hiking in nature, but the forecast now says it will be raining most of the time they’re here.

No problem! Here are some fun things to do in Santa Fe that don’t require good weather conditions.

*Visit museums - There are lots of great museums to check out in Santa Fe. Take your guests to Meow Wolf to explore interactive, psychedelic exhibits crafted by local artists and funded by author George RR Martin, or bring them to see the Museum of Indian Arts and Culture, the New Mexico History Museum, or the Museum of International Folk Art.
*Grab a bite - Santa Fe has excellent restaurants, whether you’re looking for a tasty casual meal or a fine dining experience. CHOMP is an upscale food court hosting 4-5 popup restaurants, a bar, a dance floor, and a play area for kids. Plaza Cafe is a retro diner-style eatery serving breakfast all day as well as dinner, drinks, and desserts. Radish & Rye offers delicious upscale farm-to-table cuisine. Geronimo on Canyon Road is considered one of the best fine-dining restaurants in the country. Countless other restaurants in the area are sure to satisfy your guests’ cravings and curiosities. 
*10,000 Waves - While this famed spa is known for its beautiful scenery and outdoor hot tubs, the facility is designed to make hot tub bathing pleasant through rain, sleet, or snow. The spa also offers indoor massage and spa treatments, as well as fine dining and luxury lodging accommodations, so there’s plenty to do here, even if an outdoor soak is off the menu.
*Violet Crown Cinema - The Railyard district in Santa Fe is often recommended for its outdoor concerts and easy walking, but there are a few indoor attractions worth visiting. Violet Crown Cinema is one of them. This movie theater has standard concessions, a full kitchen menu, and a bar serving wine and beer. You can dine in the lounge or take your food and drinks into the theaters. After the movie, you can walk less than 2 blocks to an indie bookstore, ice cream shop, pizza parlor, coffee shop, brewery, and boutique shopping
*Sky Railway - Just around the corner from Violet Crown Cinema, you’ll find the Jean Cocteau, a small, historic indie theater revived by author George R.R. Martin. The novelist and patron of Santa Fe’s art scene also revived a dilapidated historical railroad line to create a luxe travel experience with Sky Railway. The train cars are outfitted in an antique style with food, drinks, and entertainment offered on board while the train travels right through the heart of Santa Fe’s Railyard district, as well as into more scenic surrounding areas.
*Tumbleroot - If your guests enjoy music, they might like to catch a show at Tumbleroot Brewery and Distillery. This spot has excellent quality drinks, diverse musical acts, a large dance floor, a gallery and merch space, and a beautiful outdoor space in the back with food trucks, a bar, and a frog pond. 
*Shopping - Santa Fe is overflowing with artisans, so the shops on the plaza are always stocked with beautifully crafted and unique pieces. In this area, window shopping is just about as entertaining as a museum visit. Even if your guests don’t end up purchasing anything, they’ll be sure to enjoy browsing.

prompt: I need to brainstorm a list of words writers can use to describe skin colors without comparing them to food or drinks. messages.content: I need to brainstorm a list of words writers can use to describe skin colors without comparing them to food or drinks. Can you give me a list that covers the full spectrum of skin tones from light to dark, including various undertones and a brief explanation of what the words mean in a literal sense?

Here’s a list of words that can be used to describe skin tone that have nothing to do with food or drink: 

-Russet (A reddish-brown color)
-Fawn (A light tan color with yellow undertones)
-Bronze (A yellow-brown metal allow with a muted shine)
-Mahogany (A warm, reddish-brown wood from a tropical tree)
-Sable (A shade of dark brown or black)
-Tawny (An orange or yellow tinted shade of brown
-Terra-Cotta (Unglazed clay pottery made in a light brownish-red or soft peach color)
-Rust  (A red-brown flaky coating that evolves on certain metals as a result of oxidation)
-Umber (A natural and highly valued pigment of dark earthy brown with yellow undertones)
-Golden (As a precious metal that gleams a radiant yellow and does not tarnish)
-Copper (A red-brown metal that gleams in shades of pink when polished)
-Amber (A fossilized resin from ancient and now-extinct trees, translucent in shades of orange, brown, and yellow)
-Khaki (A fabric made in a dull yellowish-brown color)
-Brass (An alloy of copper and zinc which is yellow)
-Topaz (A gemstone that comes in many colors but is perhaps best known as Imperial Topaz, a richly hued stone of amber, orange, or honey yellow)
-Sepia (A red-brown spectrum commonly associated with 19th-century photography)
-Taupe (A shade of grey with brown undertones)
-Teak (Wood from a tree native to India and Southeast Asia known for its durability)
-Redwood (A tree species with reddish-brown bark and wood)
-Onyx (A type of quartz that is typically black with reddish undertones)
-Sienna (A rust-rich earth which is often used as a pigment in paint, bearing a yellow-brown shade when used raw or a red-brown when burned)
-Ivory (The substance which composes the tusks of an elephant, narwhal, or walrus, a creamy beige that is almost white)
-Porcelain (A white ceramic that is often used for dishware or figurines)
-Ebony (A dark brown or black wood from a tropical tree species)
-Ochre (An earthy pigment that is typically light yellow to brownish-red)

These would be songs to play during the dinner and speeches before the dance floor opens up, so I’m looking for classic retro songs about love rather than modern dance hits. prompt: What are some benefits of doing a glute bridge regularly?

The glute bridge is an exercise used to strengthen the glute muscles and the core muscles. Performing the glute bridge regularly in your exercise routine can have many benefits for your health, including:

- Building stronger glute muscles to help alleviate the tension and pressure in your lower back

- Building more strength that will help in performing more difficult exercises

The glute bridge should be performed in 3 sets of 10 for 3-4 times per week for maximum benefits.

prompt: I want to get in shape but I need ideas for exercises that I can do for my legs, but I don't have any weights to use.  Can you give me a list and explain how to do them?

messages.content: I want to get in shape but I need ideas for exercises that I can do for my legs, but I don't have any weights to use.  Can you give me a list and explain how to do them?

Here are some exercises you can do to train your legs without needing weights. 

1. Squats
Squats have long been regarded as the best way to build strong legs and butt. The squat mainly works your quads, glutes, and core but will also work your hamstrings to a lesser extent.

To do a squat stand with your feet hip or shoulder width apart in a stable stance. From there, push your hips back as if you were going to sit down. While the hips are moving back, let your knees bend and move down until you feel the strain. Be sure to try and maintain vertical shins throughout the exercise. Once you are at your lowest point, you can begin to push yourself back up to a standing position. You can make this harder by adding a heavy backpack or holding something in each hand so long as the objects are equal in weight.

2. Jump Squat
Similar to the standard squat, you can use a jump squat to improve your power and increase the intensity of the exercise. A jump squat will be more beneficial when building your fast-twitch muscle fibers. 

Performing a jump squat is as easy as it sounds. Start off in a squat position and perform a standard squat. Once you are at your low point, use the power in your legs to jump up and make sure to land softly in the same position you started. Try to maintain form with this exercise. Keeping your legs controlled when jumping will also help to increase core strength. 

3. Lunge
A lunge requires immense stability as you split your hips in half. A great exercise for your glutes, quads, and hamstrings, a lunge can be done pretty much anywhere. A lunge will also help you work your hip stabilizers as you try to maintain balance. 

A lunge is done by standing in a normal position with your feet. From here, extend one leg backward until both of your knees are at a 90-degree angle. Your front knee should not go past your toes. From here, push off with your back leg to regain your original stance. Repeat this for both legs as many times as you wish.

4. Jump Lunge
Just as a jump squat increases your fast-twitch muscle fibers, so will a jump lunge. A great exercise for building power in your legs. This exercise is not easy, so be careful when trying it, and ensure you are comfortable with a standard lunge first. 

To do a Jump lunge, get into a lunge position as you would normally. From the point where your knees are bent, you can now jump up and alternate your legs in the air. This should be performed in a controlled way so that you land softly. 

5. Side Lunge
A side lunge is similar to a normal lunge but has key differences. Firstly this exercise will work your abductors, glutes, and quads. Working different leg muscles on a lateral plane rather than a linear one is a good exercise. This is important as the range of motion we experience with our legs daily is large. 

Start off in a standing position. Next, move one leg out to the side. Imagine it's just one leg in a normal squat position. Your knee should be bent but not past your toes. Your other leg should be straight. From here, simply return to standing and alternate the legs as you go. 

6. Sumo Squat
We've done normal squats, so now here is the sumo squat. The sumo squat pays particular attention to your adductors, glutes, and quads. 

Start off by standing as a sumo with your legs wider than your shoulders to where it is comfortable. Keep your toes slightly pointed away from your body. From this position, perform a squat as you would usually, and again, be sure that your knee doesn't extend past your foot and that your shin stays as vertical as it can.

prompt: Hello. I'm working on my bucket list and added going to Siberia to my list. Please tell me about some must-see places in Siberia. Use the place name as the paragraph title. Also, tell me where in Siberia the place is located. Keep the tone cut and dry. I already know Siberia is beautiful, just give me the information about it.

messages.content: Hello. I'm working on my bucket list and added going to Siberia to my list. Please tell me about some must-see places in Siberia. Use the place name as the paragraph title. Also, tell me where in Siberia the place is located. Keep the tone cut and dry. I already know Siberia is beautiful, just give me the information about it.

No problem! Here is a list of three worthwhile places to see in Siberia.

Lake Baikal
Krasnoyarsk Territory, Western Sayan Mountains
In addition to being the largest freshwater lake in the world, Lake Baikal is also the deepest. Visitors can swim in the crystal clear water or use a boat to explore the lake. Visitors can bike or walk around the perimeter to better appreciate the size and beauty of Lake Baikal. Fishing enthusiasts can try their hand at catching omul and grayling fish. Visitors will enjoy a visit to the city of Irkutsk, which is about 45 minutes from Lake Baikal that has museums and local merchant stores to explore. 

Altai Mountains
Altai Territory, Altai Republic
The Altai Mountains are near the Russian borders of Kazakhstan, Mongolia, and China. The mountains have something for everyone: swimming in the rivers, hiking, biking, mountain climbing, and exploring caves. Some of the caves have petroglyphs and stone carving dating back to the Bronze Age about around 2000-1000 BC. Horseback riders will enjoy trekking through the beautiful forest. In winter, visitors can enjoy skiing and snowboarding. 
 
Chara Sands
Zabaykal Territory (sometimes known as Transbaikal)
In southeast Siberia, about 25 miles away from the Kodar Glaciers, sit the Chara Sands. The hot sands, tall dunes, and chains of dunes are encircled by fields of ice and frozen lakes. Like a traditional oasis, visitors can walk through the sand, relax in a cool lake and pick fresh berries from nearby bushes. The more adventurous can climb the Marble Gorge in the Kodar Mountain Range and see what is left of Soviet BorLAD, one of Stalin's secret prisons.

prompt: Can you suggest a list of ways I can bond with my cat? Please note that my cat is not too active, so games that involve running around won't work.

messages.content: Can you suggest a list of ways I can bond with my cat? Please note that my cat is not too active, so games that involve running around won't work.

Sure! Here are some ways you can bond with your cat that don't involve them being too active.

1. Treats: Treats are a great way to bond with your feline companion. You can use handheld Churo treats if you want your cat to come close to you, as many cats love licking those treats.
2. Toy Mice: Although some toys involve cats running around a lot, toy mice tend to be better as your cat can play with them in one spot if they choose to. Sit on the floor with your cat and toss them some toy mice, encouraging them to play. You can also get toy mice that have squeakers or catnip, both of which will further encourage your cat to get involved.
3. Petting: Petting is a great, underrated way to bond with your cat. Make sure you take note of where your cat likes to be petted. Most cats don't like being touched on their belly, but some love head scratches! You can test this out by gently petting them in different places and looking for signs that they do or don't enjoy what's going on. If they don't enjoy it, try switching to petting them in a different place.
4. Catnip: Providing catnip is a good way to bring your cat close to you. Try putting some in objects that are near you, as they'll attract your cat to come closer.
5. Give Them Space: Believe it or not, giving your cat space can be a great way to bond with a skittish cat. Some cats would prefer to come to you rather than you coming to them, especially if they're new to your household. Chill near them, but don't force them to interact, and you might notice it's not long before your cat is sliding closer and warming up to you.

Remember that all cats are different, so it's important to observe your cat's personality and learn their likes and dislikes. By doing this, you'll quickly find the best way to bond with them.

messages.content: My mother is retiring and will move to Florida this summer.  She loves to garden, but she's moving into an apartment building.  She's going to miss her plants, so I would like to surprise her with some that will be perfect for her apartment.  Give me a numbered list of five houseplants that will thrive in a Florida apartment and tell me a little about each one.  I'm not as plant savvy as my mother.

Sure, I am happy to help you with your request. Even house plants can be very picky when it comes to Florida's heat and humidity, but here are five suggestions of plants that should grow very well in your mother's new apartment:

1: Aloe vera is a hardy little succulent. It is a very easy plant to grow, even for beginning gardeners or someone who does not have much time to tend to a plant. Not only is it beautiful, but it also has medicinal qualities and is used to soothe sunburns, cuts, and even constipation. It comes in several varieties, including hedgehog and tiger tooth. It can be damaged due to overwatering or too much sunlight.
2: Jade plants are another succulent variety that can grow well in Florida. It is a stunningly beautiful plant that comes in several varieties, including dwarf and silver dollar. It is very easy to keep alive as it requires very little maintenance. All it requires is water, but be careful not to overwater it.
3: For someone who might not like succulents, peace lilies are both pleasing to the eye and very versatile. They can grow in pots, hanging baskets, or even low-floral planters. They, too, have different types of peace lilies, including the Sonia peace and white stripe varieties. Other than overwatering, the biggest threat to a peace lily is its delicate nature. It would be best not to touch or move them too often.
4: Orchids come in an array of colors and types and thrive in Florida homes. Whether you choose the cattleya, oncidium, or dendrobium orchid, you are going to be in for a treat with these beautiful flowers. The only threat to an orchid is too much water. It is recommended by many home gardeners to use an ice cube when it comes to watering your orchid.
5: Basil is more of an herb than a houseplant, but it is used in many recipes and makes for a great windowsill plant. It only requires water once or twice a week. While it is one of the easiest herbs to grow, it is also susceptible to diseases including rot, blight, and fungus.

prompt: Come up with some tips on how to increase the likelihood of receiving grant funding.

messages.content: Come up with some tips on how to increase the likelihood of receiving grant funding.

Sure! Here is a list of tips on how to increase the chances of winning grant money. 

Grant writing can be an intimidating feat, but also an important aspect of business and community development. Here are some tips to increase your chances of winning funds: 

1. The first tip is to thoughtfully target funders. Grant funding research indicates that most awardees receive funding from private foundations, and after that, community foundations and corporations. So, while government grants tend to offer larger sums of money, they are harder to win. 

2. Though there is no magic number for the number of grant applications you should do, try and submit three at a minimum. Like any application process, the more you submit, the greater chance you’ll have of receiving a “yes.” Completing multiple grant applications is also good practice; you’ll likely get better and faster with each proposal. 

3. Well-researched grant proposals are more likely to be funded. This part of the application will take time and planning. If you don’t feel up to it or have a grant writer in-house, consider hiring a grant writer to help with this part, or with the entire application. 

4. It may seem obvious, but it’s imperative to meet the eligibility requirements. Sometimes grant applicants think that if the project or program is good enough and the proposal and well-written, funders may let it slide. More often than not, funders are looking for ways to eliminate applications due to the high number of applications received. Not meeting the eligibility requirements is a surefire way to get your proposal eliminated from consideration. 

5. Pay attention to all of the application’s formatting requirements and guidelines. This is another way your proposal can be quickly eliminated if you do not follow the guidelines to a tee. Funders want to trust that you are detail-oriented and compliant with their standards and requests from the start. 

6. Ensure you submit a readable and error-free proposal. Bear in mind it will be another person or a group of people that review your grant application. The better the readability, the more likely the reviewers will be able to understand your objectives. Especially if you are writing in a second language or if you aren’t keen on writing in general, again, consider hiring a professional grant writer to make sure your proposal is a well-written compelling argument that explains your objectives. 

7. Make your proposal unique. As mentioned above, funders are only human, and they will be able to determine patterns in applications. Try not to base your proposal on templates off the internet or copy another proposal. It takes more time and effort to be unique and authentic, but the rewards are greater. 

8. You’ll want to have your finances in order, because funders may request additional materials that indicate you, your business, or your program is fiscally responsible.

9. Play on your strengths. If you can prove without a doubt that the work you or your organization employs benefits the community, you’re in a good position. Additionally, specific programs are more likely to receive funding than startup or operational costs.

prompt: Please provide a list of common early pregnancy symptoms.

messages.content: Please provide a list of common early pregnancy symptoms.

Sure! Here is a list of common early pregnancy symptoms that may take place within the first trimester: 

1) Missed period- If you have missed your expected period start date by a week or more, odds are that this might mean you are pregnant. This may be less reliable if you have a consistently irregular menstrual cycle.
2) Tender, swollen breasts- Your breasts may feel generally sensitive or sore or you may experience sharp pains in your breasts and/or nipples. This symptom may lessen after a few weeks.
3) Nausea with or without vomiting- This is often referred to as morning sickness, although it can occur at any time of day. It will usually begin 1-2 months into pregnancy.
4) Increased urination- This is likely because, with increased blood, your kidneys produce more fluid and this fluid ends up in your bladder.
5) Fatigue- No one knows for certain what causes sleepiness during the first trimester of pregnancy although, a rapid rise in the levels of the hormone progesterone during early pregnancy might contribute. 
6) Moodiness- You may be unusually emotional and weepy or experience mood swings.
7) Bloating- This is also due to hormonal changes. It may be similar to what you have experienced at the start of a regular menstrual period.
8) Light spotting- Light spotting may be normal in the first 12 weeks, especially around the time that your period would have started. Spotting at this point is known as implantation bleeding. It happens when the fertilized egg attaches to the lining of the uterus — about 10 to 14 days after conception. Not all women will experience this.
9) Cramping- Some women experience mild uterine cramping early in pregnancy, similar to those of your menstrual cycle, although they may feel quite different.
10) Constipation- Hormonal changes cause your digestive system to slow down, which can lead to constipation.
11) Food aversions- You might become more sensitive to certain odors and your sense of taste might change. 
12) Nasal congestion- Increasing hormone levels and blood production can cause the mucous membranes in your nose to swell, dry out and bleed easily. This might cause you to have a stuffy or runny nose.

prompt: I’m going to New Zealand and I want some unusual things to do while on holiday. I know about the main stuff, and I want some good places to show off on Instagram.

messages.content: I’m going to New Zealand and I want some unusual things to do while on holiday. I know about the main stuff, and I want some good places to show off on Instagram.

Here is a list of unusual places to visit in the North Island of New Zealand where you can take some impressive photos:

1. Waitomo Glowworm Caves (Waitomo, Waikato): Unique cave system where you can go tubing, abseiling, and ziplining under the bioluminescence of glowworms. A mix of adventure and nature, the glowworm caves are unlike anywhere else on the North Island!

2. Velocity Valley (Rotorua, Bay of Plenty): Experience the thrill of racing in a monorail capsule on an undulating course. These pedal-powered capsules are finished in shiny chrome and are both unique and unusual.

3. Toothbrush Fence (Te Pahu, Waikato): Interesting, if a little gross, you can visit a fence decorated with used toothbrushes, including ones from famous personalities such as a past Prime Minister and Flight of the Conchords stars. New Zealand has a tradition of adorning fences with collections of things - but this is certainly something else.

4. Claphams National Clock Museum (Whangarei, Northland): If you have time in Northland, the Clock Museum offers access to the largest clock collection in the southern hemisphere. The collection includes unique and rare clocks and is located conveniently near good restaurants, too.

5. Zealong Tea Estate (Gordonton, Hamilton, Waikato): The only tea plantation in New Zealand, Zealong offers the chance to sit and watch the tea grow and enjoy a refreshing beverage. The Estate also offers high tea and various refreshments in a picturesque setting.

6. Stonehenge Aotearoa (Ahiaruhe, Wairarapa, Wellington): See a replica of Stonehenge and learn about ancient astronomical techniques at New Zealand's only open-air observatory.

7. Tongariro National Trout Centre (Turangi, Waikato): Discover a center dedicated to trout fishing, featuring a museum, freshwater aquarium, kids' fishing pond, and blue duck conservation center. Taupo is famous for its trout fly fishing, and this is an unusual but interesting part of Turangi.

8. Ohakune Carrot Adventure Park (Ohakune, Manawatu-Whanganui): Playing on New Zealand’s habit of making outsized fruit and vegetables, you can stand next to a giant carrot and explore a vegetable-themed playground in Ohakune, the self-proclaimed carrot capital of the world.

9. Whanganui Journey (Taumarunui to Pipiriki, Manawatu-Whanganui): Experience a canoe journey along the Whanganui River, known as the only river in the world with the status of a living entity. You can’t take a selfie with a river anywhere else in the world - definitely unusual!

10. Hobbiton Movie Set (Matamata, Waikato): While the set itself is not unusual, you can take the opportunity to knock on a Hobbit’s door, and take pictures in the pub.

prompt: I feel like I spend all my time online and don't have any motivation to do anything productive at all. I don't get out much and i've been feeling extremely lonely and i want to find a way spend some time with other humans. Can you give me some advice on how I can develop a healthier lifestyle and stop feeling so lonely all the time? You can put your answers in a bulleted list with just a short explanation please.

messages.content: I feel like I spend all my time online and don't have any motivation to do anything productive at all. I don't get out much and i've been feeling extremely lonely and i want to find a way spend some time with other humans. Can you give me some advice on how I can develop a healthier lifestyle and stop feeling so lonely all the time? You can put your answers in a bulleted list with just a short explanation please.

Here are some ideas that may help you feel more connected and motivated:

* Make a specific schedule for activities that aren't online each day, no matter what.  It doesn't matter the activity, or the duration, just that you stick to the schedule. Committing consistently to other activities, even reading, walking, or doing chores, will eventually form better habits.

* Figure out what a few of your interests are and join a club or group related to them.  Video games and other online activities usually have some related local activities if you look. Having hobbies or interests in common is a great way for adults to make friends and start new relationships.

* Take some time and reach out to people you haven't talked to in a while, whether it's family or old friends. A call, text, or email can spark up a past relationship that only lacked a bit of effort, and believe it or not, they probably miss you too.

* Volunteering is a good way to meet new people and feel productive at the same time. You'll have a chance to do some networking, as well as help your local community.

* Going back to school is a great way to renew your motivation and social life.  It doesn't have to be full-time, or to get a degree, it can be as little as one hour a week. Education outside of your job can provide much-needed brain stimulation and many opportunities to meet classmates with similar ideas.

Do these hit the mark that you were thinking of?  Let me know if you would like any changes or other ideas.  I hope these help you feel more connected and productive.

prompt: Two nations in my fictional low fantasy setting are on the brink of war. What are some possible causes?

messages.content: Two nations in my fictional low fantasy setting are on the brink of war. What are some possible causes?

Low fantasy settings are known for their more realistic scenarios, where magic and the supernatural are not as widespread or pervasive. As such, here are some possible causes of war in your setting:

1. Territorial claims: Perhaps the recent succession of a ruler or the annulment of a marriage has made the ownership of a desirable territory disputed. Perhaps it is not the desirability of the territory, but rather the political situation that necessitates war. One nation, out of concern for how others may perceive them if they do not enforce their claims, feels obligated to act aggressively. 
2. Resources: A magical catalyst essential in the production of vital medicines is available in a key region. Ownership of it would prolong the rule and the perceived stability of the nation's leadership who controls it. 
3. Preemptive strike: The rapid economic growth of one nation has stoked fears that they will soon rearm and build a mighty military. The other nation believes they must be stopped before that can come to pass.
4. Buffer state: Out of fears that another, larger empire would consume one of the nations and use them as a staging area for an invasion, one nation feels it is necessary to invade them to set up a buffer state that is friendly to their interests.

What do you think? I can provide further help with worldbuilding if you wish.

prompt: Hi, please brainstorm three ways I can get popular on Twitter WITHOUT using hashtags. A lot of the bigger accounts don't even use them. I'll do anything except pay for followers.

messages.content: Hi, please brainstorm three ways I can get popular on Twitter WITHOUT using hashtags. A lot of the bigger accounts don't even use them. I'll do anything except pay for followers.

Awesome. Try these methods to gain Twitter followers:

1. Follow other people. Many accounts will follow back just because you followed them, increasing your follower count with real people instead of bots. Just don't follow them and unfollow them an hour later--that gets you kicked out of Twitter circles.
2. Share lots of pictures. Images are much more eye-catching than text, and they make your profile an attractive collage. You can add text to your tweet, such as "love this Versace dress," to make it searchable.
3. Reply to other people's posts. They'll appreciate the engagement and might follow you in return. Make sure you leave quality responses, not spammy comments like "lol" and "hot."

prompt: Can you recommend eight dog breeds that are good for beginners? I don't want a large dog, so nothing that gets to typically 80+lb.

messages.content: Can you recommend eight dog breeds that are good for beginners? I don't want a large dog, so nothing that gets to typically 80+lb.

No problem! Here are eight small to medium-sized dog breeds that are good for beginners:

1. Golden Retrievers: Golden Retrievers are long-haired dogs that are generally friendly and easy to train. They tend to be very attached to their families and eager to please them, which makes this dog a good choice for those who have never trained a dog.
2. Beagles: Beagles are small dogs that weigh under 30lb and are curious and active. They're perfect for someone looking for an exercise buddy.
3. Cavalier King Charles Spaniel: These small dogs are easy to manage and are usually gentle and loving. 
4. Cocker Spaniel: Cocker Spaniels are notoriously great with other animals and people and are fun and easy-going. They are also tolerant of children, making them ideal for families.
5. Bichon Frise: These dogs are small and playful, though they do take some grooming maintenance. Much like the spaniel breeds, they are easy to manage due to their small size and willingness to please.
6. Boxers: Although energetic and protective, Boxers are a common choice for first-time owners due to their willingness to learn and their ability to bond with their owners.
7. Shih Tzus: Shih Tzus are small and affectionate dogs that are great for people who live in apartments or smaller homes. They're also good with children.
8. Poodles: For first-time owners seeking a higher-energy dog, Poodles are intelligent, fun-loving, and quick to learn tricks! They can, however, be a lot for those who aren't looking to do a lot of activity with their pup.

Please remember that dogs are all individuals, and these personality traits typical of the breeds are not a guarantee.

prompt: I’m visiting Athens in august and have no clue what to do in the city aside from see the parthenon. I am really interested in the ancient history. What are a few sites worth seeing while I’m there?

messages.content: I’m visiting Athens in august and have no clue what to do in the city aside from see the parthenon. I am really interested in the ancient history. What are a few sites worth seeing while I’m there?

Athens was one of the most historically significant sites of the ancient world and has a ton of awesome temples. Here are a few of them:

- Acropolis: The Acropolis is where the Parthenon is located, however, the Acropolis has tons of buildings other than the Parthenon. There’s the Theater of Dionysus, Erechtheion, and Odeon of Herodes Atticus. 

- Ancient Agora: The Ancient Agora was used as a marketplace and public gathering place for nearly 5000 years. It’s home to the Temple of Hephaestus and Stoa of Attalos. The Temple of Hephaestus is one of the best-preserved temples in Greece.

- Temple of Olympian Zeus: The Temple of Olympian Zeus was one of the largest ancient temples. Even after being pillaged, it remains a grand sight to behold.

prompt: I’m taking a brief trip to Pittsburgh this weekend, what are some cool sites or things to do around the city? Any parks worth visiting or seeing? In the past, I’ve gone to mount Washington and station square but I’d love to see more, as well as cool stuff in those areas. I love public and historic sites and parks, as well as any buildings that are just cool to look at.

messages.content: I’m taking a brief trip to Pittsburgh this weekend, what are some cool sites or things to do around the city? Any parks worth visiting or seeing? In the past, I’ve gone to mount Washington and station square but I’d love to see more, as well as cool stuff in those areas. I love public and historic sites and parks, as well as any buildings that are just cool to look at.

- Point State Park: Point state park is one of the best in the city. It’s located where the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers meet to form the Ohio River. The area played a big role in the French and Indian War in the mid-1700s, and it houses the Fort Pitt Museum and Fort Pitt Block House, as well as the Three Rivers Heritage Trail. There are tons of plaques, monuments, and markers that detail the park’s history. It’s also a great place to watch the sunset.

- The Cathedral of Learning: The Cathedral is one of the most stunning landmarks in Pittsburgh. The Cathedral of Learning is a 42-story skyscraper and is home to many classrooms, libraries, a theater, and many other things. When it was built, it was the tallest building in the city, and it is still the second-tallest educational building in the world.

- Old Allegheny County Jail: This prison was open for a hundred years between the late 1800s and late 1900s. A bridge called the Bridge of Sighs connects it to the courthouse. It’s now a museum, and you are able to do self-guided tours. 

- Fort Pitt Museum: The Fort Pitt Museum tells of the history of the role western Pennsylvania played during events in US history like the French and Indian War and the American Revolution. There are many figures and artifacts throughout the two-story museum, and it’s a must-visit if you’re looking for history.

- The Duquesne Incline: The Incline is an iconic part of the city and, once up on Mount Washington, you can get incredible views of the city. The incline is over 100 years old and opened in the late 1800s. Once on Mount Washington, there are plenty of restaurants overlooking the city, as well as scenic outlooks.

prompt: Home automation is all the hype these days and I am wondering if it’s a good investment. Can you give me some reasons why it is? I’m away from home often, so I want to know how it can help me when I’m away. Only give me information on that. I’d like to have some control and oversight on what’s going on in my house when I’m away.

messages.content: Home automation is all the hype these days and I am wondering if it’s a good investment. Can you give me some reasons why it is? I’m away from home often, so I want to know how it can help me when I’m away. Only give me information on that. I’d like to have some control and oversight on what’s going on in my house when I’m away.

Sure! Here are some reasons why a home automation system may be a good investment for you if you stay away from home often:

1.	Cost-savings: Home automation saves you money by lowering your utility costs and reducing trips home to turn off appliances. It gives you total control of your expenses and reduces your additional effort.

2.	Secures Your Home with Automated Locking:  Automated door locks are a key feature in a home automation system. It locks the doors with a single tap. When you’re away, you can always check if your home is locked and secure. Live monitoring even allows you to see who might enter your home in real-time from anywhere in the world. It is especially useful if you have children who may forget to lock the doors before leaving.

3.	Security Cameras with Live Monitoring: Home automation systems make it easy to keep an eye on what is going on in and around the house. Security cameras capture movement even when you're not there. You’ll always know everything that happens inside the house.

4.	Thermostat Control: With home automation, you can change the temperature in your home a few hours before returning home so it is at your desired temperature when you arrive. It saves energy and is cost-effective.

5.	You Can Control Lighting and Home Appliance From Anywhere: Home automation will provide increased safety for your family and house by allowing you to manage lighting and appliances through technological gadgets. You can control it all from anywhere. Smart-home automation lets you easily check if everything is turned off when not in use.

6.	You’ll Save Valuable Time: With the high-tech features of home automation, you no longer need to rush home to answer the door, adjust household items or worry about everything on your to-do list. It saves time and increases productivity, especially for someone like you.

prompt: I am having trouble training my dog to go to the bathroom outside. Can you provide some different methods I could try?

messages.content: I am having trouble training my dog to go to the bathroom outside. Can you provide some different methods I could try?

Potty training your dog to go outside can be hard. Here are some helpful tips for you to try.

1. Outdoor Confinement: Create a small area of confinement outdoors. When your dog wakes in the morning, take them to this area of confinement and stand back. If your dog goes to the bathroom within the first ten minutes praise them. However, if they do not bring the dog back inside, keep them on a short leash under your watch. If the dog tries to go to the bathroom inside, interrupt them and take them back to the area of confinement. Slowly ween your dog out of the area of confinement once they are fully using this area within 10 minutes.

2. Bells: Hang bells on your door knob. Each time you go outside use your dog's paw to tap the bells. The idea behind this is that when the dog needs to go to the bathroom, it will tap the bells, alerting you to the fact they need to go outside. 

3. Be Alert: Be alert to your dog's elimination patterns. Do they need to go to the bathroom after eating, sleeping, or playing? If there is a pattern, you can easily take your dog outside after these activities. This also includes signs your dog is exhibiting when needing to go outside to potty, such as:
     • Spinning in circles.
     • Going to areas where they have previously had accidents.
     • Hiding in another room, around corners, behind furniture.
     • Scratching or barking at the door. 

4. Timer: Set a timer! Sometimes we can lose track of time if the dog is not showing signs when they need to go outside. 

Remember to practice patience and not give up. Your dog will start going outside to potty before you know it.

Of course! Adding perennials to your garden will give you a burst of color and fragrance year after year. Here are five perennial flowers to add to your garden:

1. Lilacs: This fragrant flower grows on a large bush and returns more prominent and beautiful every year. It comes in a vibrant purple and will have your backyard smelling wonderful for several weeks while they are in bloom. 
2. Hydrangea: The hydrangea is a bush flower that produces flowers ranging from deep blues to deep purples. Flowers are grown in tight bunches and add the perfect pop to your garden.
3. Wisteria: Wisterias are a vining type of flower and are great for climbing to add color and fragrance to an area you might not normally be able to get to. They come in light purple, white, and pink-purple. They are great for creating a natural outdoor ceiling or adding beauty to any fence.
4. Lavender: This flower is light purple, fragrant, and a flower the bumblebee cannot refuse. One benefit is lavender can help with sleep. Drying lavender and placing it in a bowl near your bed can help you relax before you sleep.
5. Rose: A pink rose is the perfect addition to any garden. There are many varieties of pink and fragrant roses that you can find at any nursery.

prompt: I am very interested in the Melungeon people of Appalachia, Can you tell me more information about the Melungeon People?

messages.content: I am very interested in the Melungeon people of Appalachia, Can you tell me more information about the Melungeon People?

No Problem! Here is some interesting information about the Melungeon People of Appalachia.

     1. The Melungeon People, also known as the “Lost Tribe” of Appalachia, are believed to have a mixed heritage of Native American, European, and African ancestry. Their mixed diversity is still in question by historians. 
     2. Melungeon was a derogatory word combined with the words “malungo” which means shipmate in African, and “meln jinn,” which means cursed soul in Turkish. 
     3. Melungeon skin tone varies from light to dark, showcasing their mixed heritage. The Melungeon people had been classified in the U.S census as “free persons of color.”
     4. The Melungeon people have rich diverse cultural traditions they share in storytelling, music, and culinary practice. Their diverse ancestry has created a rich folkloric heritage, mixed with the cultural aspects of the Appalachian region. 
     5. Melungeon communities were more widely known in Wise County, Virginia, and Hancock County, Tennessee. However, the Melungeon people also lived in areas of Kentucky and North Carolina.

Hang mistletoe from doorways and tie red bows for decoration. Make place cards and invitations that look like Christmas cards. Light a fire and have red and green blankets for guests to use.
3. Rustic Winter - This is an outdoor woodsy theme with acorns, pinecones, burlap, and wood signs for decorations. For greenery, use wreaths, pine needles, and evergreens. Use tree stumps to hold lanterns. Make centerpieces from small tree stumps and evergreens. Place plenty of white candles in glass jars on long wooden tables. Use gray wool or knitted blankets as accents on the backs of chairs, and light a fire if there is a fireplace.

prompt: Recently I’ve been interested in living without a phone. The one thing is I want to know how to figure out the time. Can you tell me some of the ways I can keep track of time without a phone? You can even give me the simplest options because I’m drawing blanks at the moment.

messages.content: Recently I’ve been interested in living without a phone. The one thing is I want to know how to figure out the time. Can you tell me some of the ways I can keep track of time without a phone? You can even give me the simplest options because I’m drawing blanks at the moment.

I can absolutely do that for you, and I’ll give you some of the simplest options to help.

1. Watch - This one seems like a no-brainer, but it can be easy to forget about since so many people have phones. Watches can run for cheap, and if you don’t want to carry a phone around, you can opt for a watch to help you keep tabs on the time at all times.
2. Find a clock - Tons of places still have clocks hanging up somewhere. However, it is less common now because of the widespread use of phones.
3. Ask someone - If you don’t have a watch and there’s no clock, you can also ask someone. If you’re in a store or somewhere with employees, you can ask them. You can also ask coworkers and friends if you’re working or out and about with others.
4. Look at the sun - This will only give you a relative track of what time it is, but it can help. When the sun is halfway up in the sky, it’s about noon. It also rises in the East and sets in the West. By looking at where the sun is in the sky, you can get a relative idea of the time.
5. Get some other cheap device that tells the time - Even Tomagachi’s have ways to tell the time. If you don’t want to keep a phone, but you’re fine with some other piece of tech you’re less tied to, try to find another device that tells the time. Most handheld video game consoles will tell you what time it is, and some can fit right in your pocket. There are also analog and digital pocket clocks that exist just for this reason.

prompt: I'm about to start learning dancing, and I already know I'm going to be horrible at it. Help me brainstorm different ideas and things I could do to make learning it a bit easier and how each idea might help.

- Research - Along with watching, you can also learn some of the different terms you may have to use during your classes. Even if you don't know what these terms mean, knowing the words will give you a little bit of a head start.

I hope you succeed in learning to dance!

prompt: Suggest five places to go on a hiking-centric vacation. Only recommend locations within the western United States. Please describe a bit about each location so I can get a sense of whether it's a good fit for where I want to go.

messages.content: Suggest five places to go on a hiking-centric vacation. Only recommend locations within the western United States. Please describe a bit about each location so I can get a sense of whether it's a good fit for where I want to go.

No problem, here are five suitable destinations for a hiking-centric vacation within the western United States along with a description of each location: 

1. Sedona, Arizona. With many highly acclaimed hiking spots like Cathedral Rock, Devil's Bridge, and Soldier's Pass, Sedona has no shortage of beautiful landscapes. If you are looking for a more unique hiking experience, consider trying a vortex or yoga hike during your stay, or perhaps finding one of Sedona's many incredible stargazing locations.
2. Joshua Tree National Park. Located in southern California, Joshua Tree has a wide variety of hiking trails, making it a perfect destination for hikers of all ability levels. If you are looking for something less difficult, consider one of the park's short, circular walks and nature trails that are accessible year-round. If you are in the mood for a challenge, try your hand at one of the multi-day treks intended for advanced hikers. Remember to check ahead if you plan to check out one of the more advanced trails because they are only open at certain times of the year.         
3. Olympic National Park. Located just outside of Seattle, Washington, Olympic National Park is a diverse and beautiful destination that spans close to a million acres. Due to its immense size, visitors are treated to a wide variety of ecosystems and terrains, so whether you prefer to hike in lush rainforests, alpine regions, rugged coastal wilderness, or immense dry areas, you will be able to find something for you here. With more than 611 miles of trails, the park has trails suitable for hikers of all skill levels. 
4. Malibu, California. If you are interested in ocean breezes and taking in beautiful coastal panoramas as you hike, look no further than Malibu in southern California as the destination for your hiking-centric vacation. With a wide variety of trails offering ocean views, Malibu is perfect for hikers of all abilities that want to explore the coastline and take in the majesty of the Pacific Ocean. 
5. Grand Canyon. One of the most famous hiking destinations not only within the western United States but on the entire planet, the Grand Canyon truly has everything you could want as a hiker. With easily accessible pathways, sightseeing routes, and numerous stops along the South Rim of the Canyon, it's not difficult to find a beautiful vista. This Arizona landmark has a wide variety of hiking trails, so whether you are interested in a casual stroll or a serious hike away from the crowds, you should be able to find just what you're looking for. 

I hope that you've found these recommendations helpful as you consider a destination for your vacation. Happy hiking!

prompt: I want a list of Irish names for a girl baby and what they mean. Make sure to give me at least 8 options. {Number}.{Name}:{Meaning}

messages.content: I want a list of Irish names for a girl baby and what they mean. Make sure to give me at least 8 options. {Number}.{Name}:{Meaning}

You got it! Here are ten Irish girl names and what they mean: 

1. Aoife: Found in several Irish legends, the name Aoife means “beauty” in Gaelic. 
2. Erin: Meaning “Ireland,” from the Irish Gaelic word Éire, this anglicized name is a beautiful way to name a girl after the country itself. 
3. Fiona: Fíona derives from the word fíon, meaning “wine,” and while it was once quite popular, it’s slightly rarer now. 
4. Maeve: Meaning “intoxicating,” Maeve is the anglicized form of the Irish girl’s name Medb, who was a Celtic warrior queen. 
5. Niamh: Technically, Niamh is both a boy's and a girl's name, and it means “bright.” In Irish mythology, Niamh was the daughter of the sea god Manannán mac Lir. 
6. Saoirse: One of the more popular Irish girl's names is Saoirse, which means “freedom” in Gaelic.
7. Talulla: Anglicized form of several Old Irish female names, including Taileflaith, Tuileflaith, and Tuilelaith; Talulla means both “abundance” and “ruler, princess.”
8. Aisling: The Irish version of the popular name Ashley, Aisling means “dream” or “vision.” 
9. Bridget: A popular anglicized version of the old Irish name Brighid, Bridget means “the exalted one.
10. Doireann: This name links to two Irish words, Der for “daughter” and Finn for “fair,” which means the name is literally “fair daughter.”

prompt: I’m going to a Halloween party! Give me a list of popular Halloween costumes. I only want ideas for traditional scary Halloween costumes ideas. List format. Give me some prop ideas or a few pieces of clothing I would need for each costume.

messages.content: I’m going to a Halloween party! Give me a list of popular Halloween costumes. I only want ideas for traditional scary Halloween costumes ideas. List format. Give me some prop ideas or a few pieces of clothing I would need for each costume.

No problem! Here is a list of traditional and scary Halloween costumes ideas:  

1. Ghost - 
Dressing up like a ghost on Halloween is a popular and classic costume choice. To dress up like a ghost for Halloween, you can simply drape a white sheet over your head and body. Be sure to cut two eye holes in the sheet so you can see where you’re walking!

2. Vampire - 
A vampire Halloween costume usually uses some notable costume props such as false vampire teeth, white face makeup, and fake blood or red cosmetics to imitate blood. You can also choose to wear a cape or a flowing black robe to complete the look for your vampire Halloween costume.

3. Zombie - 
A zombie is another classic horror Halloween costume choice that is easy to make. To dress up like a zombie for Halloween, you can use simple props like fake blood and some torn or dirt-covered clothing. Complete your zombie Halloween costume with a silly, staggered zombie-style walk!  

4. Witch -
Witches are classic and scary Halloween costumes that have many cultural variations and styles. For the most traditional witch Halloween costume, however, there are a few staple characteristics: a large false nose and green face makeup should complete the look. For costume props, you might include a witches broom, a magic wand, or a pointy witch hat – just to name a few!

5. Skeleton - 
What could be more classically creepy than a skeleton suit or costume on Halloween? All you need for this traditional scary costume is some black and white face paint, or simply painted white bones on dark clothing!

prompt: Can I get a list of things to do while visiting Toronto?  I want there to be 7 items on the list and the activities should be kid friendly.

messages.content: Can I get a list of things to do while visiting Toronto?  I want there to be 7 items on the list and the activities should be kid friendly.

Of course! Here are 7 popular kid-friendly activities to check out while visiting Toronto:

1. Ripley's Aquarium of Canada:  Ripley’s Aquarium has nearly 20,000 animals including sharks, jellyfish, octopuses, manta rays, sea turtles, and a variety of tropical fish.

2. Toronto Zoo:  Canada’s largest zoo has over 5,000 animals from various areas around the world including Africa, North and South America, Australia, Asia, and even the Arctic.

3. CN Tower:  Ride in a glass elevator to the top of the iconic CN Tower for breathtaking views of the city.

4. Ontario Science Centre:  Kids of all ages will be sure to enjoy the interactive exhibits, hands-on learning experiments, and IMAX movies.

5. Legoland:  Children and their imaginations can run wild in this Lego-themed park featuring rides, a 4D movie theatre, and several open play areas with plenty of Legos.

6. Canada’s Wonderland:  The largest theme park in Canada has roller coasters for people of all ages, live shows, and an adjacent water park called Splash Works.

7. Royal Ontario Museum:  Attractions include an extensive collection of dinosaur skeletons, a discovery gallery, a bat cave simulation, and various cultural exhibits from around the world. 

These are just a few options for family-friendly fun in Toronto.  Be sure to check the hours of operation before visiting any of these venues.

prompt: What are three of the most dangerous hikes in the United States? I want to do something new, but I'll also need safety tips.

Here are a few ideas for your next adventure:
1. Mt. Washington Trail Peak: Take a 12-mile trek in New Hampshire up the highest mountain in the northeastern United States. With an elevation of 6,288 feet, extreme weather, and winds at 231 miles per hour, this hike is highly dangerous.
2. Barr Trail: Hike 12 miles in Manitou Springs, Colorado, to the top of this trail. After six to ten hours and reaching elevations of 7,500 feet, you will be welcomed with a view of Manitou Springs and Pikes Peak.
3. Angel's Landing: Watch your step in Zion National Park, Utah. With narrow trails above sheer cliffs, this is one of the most dangerous hikes. There are about two deaths each year. But the trail ends with a breathtaking view.

prompt: So I'm working on a sort of lighter, skirmisher kind of character for my turn-based tactical game. What are some of the abilities that would work for them?

messages.content: So I'm working on a sort of lighter, skirmisher kind of character for my turn-based tactical game. What are some of the abilities that would work for them?

Sure, I can help you brainstorm such a character's abilities. Here are some that may make them a useful addition to the player's team:

1. Maneuver: This ability would allow the character to traverse enemy-controlled tiles without inciting attacks of opportunity. It would allow the player to outflank the enemy or to get at a guarded enemy or objective. 
2. Blink: By blinking, the character can teleport a short distance directly to a tile in front of them. This would allow the character to bypass defenses and obstacles that would have otherwise taken several turns to break down. 
3. Sneak Attack: As a flanker, the character would specialize in doing their best work behind enemy lines and from advantageous positions. Their skillset would not only include abilities that would allow them to get to such advantageous positions but also to maximize their advantage when there. Sneak Attack, which could ensure a guaranteed critical on the next attack by the character, would fit well into this role. 
4. Caltrops: The character can toss caltrops upon the ground, slowing or outright immobilizing enemies caught in them. This would help to redirect enemy movements and to prevent more powerful enemies from catching up with the character.
5: Sucker Punch: When cornered by a formidable enemy, Sucker Punch can disable them for one turn, rendering them unable to perform attacks of opportunity. This would be ideal for getting out of danger from a more powerful opponent.
6. Second Wind: By activating Second Wind, the character can regain their movement points. This would allow the lightly equipped skirmisher character to traverse the entire map easily, suiting their role as a flanker.

Please ask if you would like me to brainstorm any other character abilities.

prompt: Hi, what are some easy-to-grow garden plants? I live in Idaho and want plants that grow well in this climate. I also want plants that are resilient to weather changes and take minimum effort to grow.

messages.content: Hi, what are some easy-to-grow garden plants? I live in Idaho and want plants that grow well in this climate. I also want plants that are resilient to weather changes and take minimum effort to grow.

Thank you for your question! I have found some garden plants that match your request.

1. Lettuce: Lettuce does well in Idaho because it can withstand frost fairly well. It is also low maintenance, requiring little watering and can grow in any type of soil. It doesn't require a lot of space, so it is great for any garden size.
2. Peas: You don't have to worry about the interaction of peas and other plants. They grow well among all plants and don't hinder the health of other plants. They thrive in cooler temperatures, meaning you can plant them early in Idaho and harvest them into late fall. They don't need much space and are a relatively hardy plant.
3. Tomatoes: Tomatoes produce well in Idaho's summer climate, making them low maintenance. They can also do well even if planted in low-quality soil. They will need a stake or vegetable cage for support and to keep the wind from damaging them.
4. Green Beans: Beans do well in Idaho summers because they are drought resistant, needing little water and doing well in direct sunlight. They also enrich the soil. Grow them once you're sure the risk of spring frost is gone. They do well growing up poles, meaning they don't need a lot of room.

All gardens require some amount of work, but these plants should be relatively easy to cultivate in Idaho. Good luck with your gardening endeavors!

prompt: I am an artist trying to grow a following so I can eventually start selling my art. What are some good websites that I can use to showcase my work and spread my brand?

messages.content: I am an artist trying to grow a following so I can eventually start selling my art. What are some good websites that I can use to showcase my work and spread my brand?

Promoting your art can be hard. It's much more than simply selling art. Many creatives have trouble building the courage to put something they make online. Creatives need a thick skin when showing off something they created with love. That being said, it doesn't need to be difficult. Posting online is a great first step, so congratulations! When you think about marketing yourself online, selling things should be the last thing on your mind. Connect with enough people, and the rest will fall into place. There are many websites to help you do this, so here are a few suggestions.

1. Instagram - Instagram is a wonderful tool for organically reaching a wide group of people. It is an image and video social media platform on which you can share fully finished works or even progress updates. Some artists even record themselves working and make videos played at faster speeds to show a full beginning to end in a short digestible video.
2. Reddit (Related Subreddits) - Reddit can be a great place to submit your art, provided you go to the right sections. There are dozens of subreddits that can be beneficial to an up-and-coming artist. The community is moderated, but because it is an open forum, you might run into some trolls.
3. Deviant Art - If you are into concept art and digital art, Deviant Art is the place to be. It has a huge community where you can follow other artists and comment on each other's work. An artist's Deviant Art page often also acts as their portfolio when applying for jobs. 
4. Pinterest - Pinterest is more of a visual search engine than a portfolio or social media page. If you put your work up on Pinterest, then others can pin it so they can add the post to their collection. They can even re-pin it so it reaches even more people.
5. Wetcanvas Forums - Wetcanvas is an art-specific forum. While Reddit is a forum with thousands of different topics, Wetcanvas is a place solely for creative art. It is a wonderful place to connect with like-minded artists, get feedback on recent work, or ask for advice on anything you may be stuck on.

prompt: I'm writing a fantasy novel. I want to include some classic races of supernatural creatures. Please give me five options I could go with, and tell me a bit about them.

messages.content: I'm writing a fantasy novel. I want to include some classic races of supernatural creatures. Please give me five options I could go with, and tell me a bit about them.

I can do that! Here are five classic supernatural creatures you might want to incorporate into your story.

1: Vampires: Vampires have been used in mythology and stories for centuries, and there have been many iterations of them. Their lore tends to be that they are undead creatures of the night, with long fangs used to drink blood, and they can often turn into bats. Some versions of vampires created for stories or present in mythology are allergic to garlic, burned by sunlight, and can only be killed by a crucifix. 
2. Werewolves: Another classic supernatural creature often presented as a mortal enemy of the vampire is the werewolf. The werewolf is a creature that presents as human most of the time but, on a full moon, turns into a wolf. Depending on the story, this may be a classic version of a wolf or it may be a more monstrous version. Legends often say that if someone is bitten by a werewolf on the full moon, they will then turn into one.
3. Ghosts: Ghosts are also supernatural creatures and subjects of many stories, and are typically humans who did not pass onto the afterlife, leaving a form of them stuck wandering the earth. Ghosts may be friendly to humans or not. There are many other names for ghosts, such as specters, spirits, and poltergeists (who are usually evil ghosts).
4. Mages: Mages are humans who have been gifted with the ability of magic, also called witches, wizards, and sorcerers. Mages may be good, evil, or inherently neither in a story, and the magic they can do may vary. Sometimes, mages are not separate creatures at all but humans who have learned to do magic. They may also have animal familiars, though this is typically for witches.
5. Demons: Born from religion, demons are also supernatural creatures that are sometimes used in fictional stories. They are creatures who have come from Hell, and may or may not have been human a long time ago, depending on the iteration of them. They are there to cause chaos and even harm to humans and usually make good villains in a story.

prompt: My daughter is having a fashion show party for her 10th birthday and I need some ideas - anything from food to decorations or activities would be good.

messages.content: My daughter is having a fashion show party for her 10th birthday and I need some ideas - anything from food to decorations or activities would be good.

Absolutely! Here are some ideas for your daughter's fashion show party:

* FASHION ATTIRE: Invite guests to wear their favorite fashions to the party and be sure to let them know there will be a runway for the fashion show. 

* RUNWAY SCHOOL: You could offer "runway lessons" in walking and posing to help guests prepare for the show.

* RUNWAY: Of course, if you're having a fashion show party, you'll probably want to create a fashion runway for the show. Consider using a curtain or some other divider to create a "backstage" for the models to use before the show. You could also set up fans around the runway to create the windblown effect. 

* AUDIENCE: What's a fashion show without an audience? Invite family members to join the fun and cheer on the models.

* MUSIC: Try to play fun, upbeat music during the show to create a realistic atmosphere. 

* HAVE AN MC: You or a volunteer could MC the show and introduce each model to make them feel special. 

* PHOTOS: As with any party, you'll want to take pictures to remember the day, but since this is a fashion show party, you might want to take even more! You could snap pictures of the actual show or individual models to showcase their fashion.

* EVERYONE'S A WINNER: If you'd like, you could give each guest (and the birthday girl) a unique award after the show such as Most Glamorous, Most Sassy, Best Hair, etc. 

* SCAVENGER HUNT: Before or after the fashion show, you could have guests participate in a fashion magazine scavenger hunt. You'll need fashion magazines you don't mind being cut up, scissors, glue or glue sticks, poster boards, and a list of items for the teams to find like high-heeled shoes, a diamond ring, a fancy hat, a pair of red lips, etc. Set a timer and see which team can collect the most items on their board before time runs out!

prompt: I'm going on vacation and deciding whether or not to stay in a hotel. Could you describe the advantages there might be in staying in an AirBnB instead?

messages.content: I'm going on vacation and deciding whether or not to stay in a hotel. Could you describe the advantages there might be in staying in an AirBnB instead?

Sure! Here are the advantages you might find when staying in an Airbnb over a hotel:

1. More Space: Airbnbs are often an entire house or apartment, meaning you have more space than in a hotel room. This is handy for long-term stays or large groups.
2. More Amenities: Because Airbnbs are usually someone's home, there are usually more amenities. For example, they may have a full kitchen where you can cook food, whereas it's unlikely a hotel will have this.
3. Cheaper Pricing: Although it's not guaranteed, Airbnbs are often less expensive than large hotels since their prices aren't dictated by a corporation. 
4. More Flexibility: For the same reason, Airbnb might have more flexibility than a hotel, which usually has firmly fixed check-in and out times dictated by the company. If you need to check in earlier or out later, an Airbnb owner might be more willing to accommodate this. They also may have more flexible cancellation policies.
5. More Pet-Friendly: Many Airbnbs are more pet-friendly than hotels, though it's important to check with the owner.
6. More Privacy: Depending on your booking, you may have more privacy in an Airbnb unlike having to cross through the hotel lobby every time you need to get in and out.

Remember, it's always important to read the reviews and policies on Airbnb accommodations before a booking, as these aren't all guaranteed.

prompt: I'm trying to learn how to meditate and am struggling to maintain focus and block distractions. Give me some tips on how to get into a regular meditation practice that I can do in the morning before work. Don't include tips that require me to go outside.

messages.content: I'm trying to learn how to meditate and am struggling to maintain focus and block distractions. Give me some tips on how to get into a regular meditation practice that I can do in the morning before work. Don't include tips that require me to go outside.

Here are some helpful tips for learning how to maintain focus during a morning meditation!

1. Start small and build up
If you have trouble maintaining focus throughout your entire meditation, start with just two or three minutes. Once your body and mind get used to the feeling of meditation, maintaining stillness will become easier. Build slowly, adding a minute or two every week. You can even set a timer so you don't have to focus on how long it's been. 

2. Use the Hong-Sau Technique
To perform the Hong-Sau Technique, sit perfectly upright with your legs folded. Slowly inhale for a count of eight, and then slowly exhale for the same count. During your inhale, say "hong" in your head. On each exhale, say "sau" in your head. Repeat six times to gain concentration and focus. 

3. Focus on comfort
Instead of trying to maintain perfect posture, try to choose a position that is comfortable for you. Find a place with limited distractions where you can feel at peace. If you're more comfortable laying down or keeping your eyes open, that's ok too. 

4. Consume raisins 
Studies show that eating about half a cup of raisins, which contain boron, can help improve focus and attentiveness. 

5. Try a guided meditation
Guided meditation can help you maintain focus and eliminate distractions by providing something to give you something to concentrate on that is related to your practice. 

6. Use earplugs
Earplugs are a great way to eliminate distractions from outside noises. Noise-canceling headphones or white noise is another way to remove noisy distractions. 

Let me know if you would like any more suggestions, or if you want me to expand on any of the ideas listed here!

prompt: My kids really like fantasy and adventure books. Can you give me some recommendations for books? I’d prefer books that are not standalone, and I’d like some recommendations for different age groups. I have readers aged 7-13.

I would be glad to give you some book suggestions for your kids! Let’s see if these hit the mark:

1. The Chronicles of Narnia by C.S. Lewis. This series is one of the most classic and well-known children's fantasy series, with a world of magic, talking creatures, and adventure. It is considered suitable for children aged 6-12.
2. Charlie and the Chocolate Factory duology by Roald Dahl. This whimsical duo of books about young Charlie and his adventures with Willy Wonka is delightful for younger readers. It is suitable for children ages 6-10.
3. The Children’s Circle Stories by Terry Pratchett.  This collection of short fantasy stories was written in the 1960s and has been collected and released as a series that will delight young readers with stories like Dragons at Crumbling Castle. This series is appropriate for readers ages 7 and up.
4. Harry Potter, by J.k. Rowling. This series of books follows young Harry as he discovers he is a wizard, and follows him on his adventures and escapades at a magical school for wizardry. This series is suitable for readers ages 8 and up.
5. Alice in Wonderland and its sequel, Through the Looking Glass, by Lewis Carroll. These classic works are fantastical and engaging. These books are appropriate for children 9 and up.
6. Howl’s Moving Castle by Diana Wynn Jones. This series is a trilogy about Sophie and the wizard Howl and their adventures with witches, wizards, and a fantastical moving castle. It is appropriate for children 9 and up.
7. The Redwall series by Brian Jacques. This series is huge, with 22 books for children to enjoy. The books follow the adventures of sentient animals as they live in communities together and fight their enemies. Because of battles and fighting in the books, they are best suited for children over the age of 9.
8. His Dark Materials by Philip Pullman. This trilogy follows the protagonist Lyra as she lives in a world where magic has been repressed by the government. It’s best for children over the age of 
9. The Inheritance Cycle by Christopher Paolini. These books are considered high fantasy, and take place in a world with magic and dragons. The themes of intrigue, revenge, and war make these books suitable for children 12 and up.

prompt: i have a job interview coming up, retail store, please brainstorm 6 job interview tips, make em good, this is my first interview (im 17), thank u!!!!!!

messages.content: i have a job interview coming up, retail store, please brainstorm 6 job interview tips, make em good, this is my first interview (im 17), thank u!!!!!!

Congratulations on your first interview! Here are six tips to polish your interview performance:

1. Arrive about 10-15 minutes early so that you can get acquainted with your surroundings and start your interview without making the interviewer feel rushed. They probably have a busy schedule, so they need to start your interview on time.
2. Make sure you dress nicely! You don't have to wear a dress or a suit and tie, but arrive in business-casual attire, which includes dress pants, long-sleeved shirts, and closed-toe shoes. If you get hired, your HR manager will tell you more about the job dress code.
3. Look up common job interview questions online, and practice answering them alone or with a friend. Note that your answers should almost always be positive even if the question seems to require a negative answer. For example, if the interviewer asks "What's your biggest flaw?", give them a minor flaw with a positive spin, such as "Sometimes, I get a little too immersed in my work."
4. Employers want extroverted employees. If you're an introvert, you don't have to invent a fake personality, but appear bubbly, friendly, and talkative. These employees work the best with customers and colleagues, making them ideal job candidates.
5. Be professional, but don't worry about being perfect. If you're too perfect, it's creepy. Make a good first impression while letting the best parts of your personality shine through.
6. Follow up within a week with a simple email or phone call, showing them that you like this employer and want to start working with them.

prompt: I'm getting ready to decorate my Christmas tree, and I want a list of brainstorming ideas with off-the-wall things I can use to decorate the Christmas tree this year that still somehow fit. Give me four or five ideas.

messages.content: I'm getting ready to decorate my Christmas tree, and I want a list of brainstorming ideas with off-the-wall things I can use to decorate the Christmas tree this year that still somehow fit. Give me four or five ideas.

There are lots of ways to decorate a Christmas tree! Here are a few that are quite unique:

- Faux Greenery: Faux greenery can be obtained in garlands, and these can be wrapped around your tree. This can make your tree look fuller, but it also may make people do a double-take if you have a fake white Christmas tree.
- Favorite Things: Have your family take all of their favorite things that are small enough to fit on the tree and hang them on it. This is very personalized and can include anything from a favorite hat to a scarf or a pair of earrings. This mismatched-looking tree decor fits perfectly, especially since it might give you gift ideas when you see some things your family members like. 
- Global-Inspired: If you've done any traveling and have collected any knickknacks from places you've been, put all of these on the tree. This can be a good way to remember some of the places you've been, and it should also spark conversations with guests who ask about them. 
- Party Decorations: Christmas is a type of party, so why not use some party decorations? These tend to be quite colorful, and often only get used a handful of times throughout the year anyway. 
- Hang Christmas Greetings: People often give out Christmas cards to all the people they know, so why not hang these up where everyone can see? You can also print out words with fancy lettering on nice paper, cut these out, and use them as ornaments on the tree. 

Let me know if you want any more ideas!

prompt: I want to decorate my new apartment, but the thing is that it’s pretty small. Can you give me some ideas to decorate it? Suggest things that can maximize storage space. Also, none of the ideas should include hanging items on the walls.

messages.content: I want to decorate my new apartment, but the thing is that it’s pretty small. Can you give me some ideas to decorate it? Suggest things that can maximize storage space. Also, none of the ideas should include hanging items on the walls.

Sure! Here are some clever ideas for decorating a small space and making the most of your apartment without damaging the walls:

1. Take a seat and store your stuff: An entryway bench not only serves as a cozy spot to put on your shoes, but it also provides hidden storage for things like shoes, bags, and umbrellas.

2. Contain your clutter with pretty storage: Invest in stylish storage containers that can stack and slide easily under furniture, such as the bed or sofa. You can store all your extra blankets, seasonal clothing, and other items without adding clutter to your living space.

3. Summon up some seating with added storage: Poufs are a perfect solution for small apartments because they function as both extra seating and hidden storage. Place them throughout your apartment to add texture and depth while also providing a space to stash your belongings.

4. Elevate Your Sleeping Quarters: Consider lofting your bed to make way for additional storage or a cozy seating area underneath.

5. Decal Delight: Similar to wallpaper, temporary decals offer unique patterns and designs that can be easily removed or swapped out at a moment's notice. It’s perfect for adding pops of color or texture to smaller spaces.
