1. Gooseberry Falls State Park: Visit this park to hike 18 miles along the mouth of the Gooseberry River. See the Lower, Middle, and Upper Gooseberry Falls. Bike eight miles of mountain bike trails. In the winter, snowshoeing, cross-country skiing, and snowmobiling.
2. Split Rock Lighthouse and State Park: Visit Superior's North Shore and the Split Rock Lighthouse. Picnic on the shore, stop in at the museum, and hike, bike, snowshoe, and cross-country ski 14 miles of trails.

prompt: I am visiting Chiang Mai in Thailand and I would like to visit 4 sights of natural beauty during the day, I have seen all the temples already. On the list, include a fifth option for a fun night-time activity too.

messages.content: I am visiting Chiang Mai in Thailand and I would like to visit 4 sights of natural beauty during the day, I have seen all the temples already. On the list, include a fifth option for a fun night-time activity too.

No problem, here are 4 sights of natural beauty to visit on your trip to Chiang Mai and a further option for a fun nighttime activity:

1. Doi Inthanon National Park - Hosting the tallest mountain in Thailand, Doi Inthanon should be a stop on your tour of natural beauty spots. Covering an area of 48,240 hectares, there is no shortage of adventures to be had. The park is also known for being home to the most variety of birds in Thailand.

2. Mae Ping River - Taking a boat trip along the stunning Mae Ping River is the perfect way to spend an afternoon. The river's edge is dotted with beautiful teak houses and lush greenery, making this a fantastic addition to your tour of Chiang Mai's natural beauty spots.

3. Chiang Mai Canyon - A hidden gem on your tour, the Canyon remains relatively unknown. Once an old soil quarry, the Canyon offers breathtaking views that will be a highlight of your trip.

4. San Kamphaeng Hot Springs - Hidden within the mountains you'll find the incredible San Kamphaeng Hot Springs. Containing a high sulfur content, the waters of the spring are said to have healing properties. You can relax in these waters in either the mineral baths or the traditional mineral swimming pool.

5. The Night Bazaar - A fun addition to your night-time activities, the Night Bazaar can be found at Chang Klan Road. Open every day of the year, the Bazaar springs to life at nighttime. Try your hand at bartering with the locals and enjoy a feast for the senses.

1. Vail Ski Resort: Located in Colorado, this well-renowned ski resort is spread out over 5,317 acres and averages nearly 30 feet of snow each year.  The town of Vail is also extremely lively and hosts a variety of restaurants, shops, and entertainment options.

prompt: I'm looking for a few places to visit in Boston.  I love historical sites and don't want to spend a ton of money.

messages.content: I'm looking for a few places to visit in Boston.  I love historical sites and don't want to spend a ton of money.

Here's a list of five sites that you can visit in Boston:

1. The Freedom Trail: The Freedom Trail is a 2.5-mile walk through Boston that will take you through the heart of the city, passing several historical sites including churches, museums, and meeting houses. While guided tours are available, you can also walk the trail on your own for free.
2. Bunker Hill Monument: This historic monument is free to access and it has a museum component to it. You can learn about the famed Revolutionary War Battle and climb to the top of Bunker Hill.
3. The Boston Public Library: This free attraction is a wonderful historic site where you can explore to appreciate the architecture, view any one of the library's nearly two million rare books and manuscripts, and even see the art collection on display.
4. The Old North Church: You can visit the North End to see the Old North Church, as well as its surrounding attractions. This is the oldest Church in Boston that is still standing today.
5. The Paul Revere House: The Paul Revere House is the oldest building in Boston. You don't have to go inside if you don't want to pay, but you can still observe its historic structure from the exterior.

prompt: What are 5 excercises to build bigger arms in the gym?

messages.content: What are 5 excercises to build bigger arms in the gym?

Here are five exercises you can do to grow your arms. 

1. Dead hang pull-up. 
The dead hang pull-up is a variation of the standard pull-up and is excellent for working your biceps. Start by grabbing a pull-up bar underhanded so your palms are facing you. Your arms should be about shoulder-width apart. Hold your weight, cross your legs behind your body, and raise your feet slightly so your knees are bent. This is your starting position. To perform the exercise, pull yourself up so that your collarbone is in line with the bar. The trick to performing this exercise is to lower yourself at a slower pace. About 4 seconds will be best. Now repeat until you are unable to do any more. 

2. Rolling skull crusher with press. 
Start by lying on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, raised straight above your chest. Now allow your elbows to bend so that the dumbbells fall beside your head in a controlled manner. Now reverse this motion so that the dumbbells are in the original position and perform a press like a bench press. Once you have completed all these motions, that's considered one rep. This exercise works your triceps and chest, so it's versatile when trying to build muscle. You can use a Swiss ball instead of a bench for more difficulty. This will work your abs as well. 

3. Drag curl.
Everyone knows that curls help to build your biceps and arms in general. This exercise is no different in that sense but is performed with some differences. Start by holding the barbell with a shoulder-width, underhand grip. Now you should pull your shoulders down and back. When doing this, you should drag the bar up the front of your body, keep your elbows around, and slowly lower the barbell. To work slightly harder, try using dumbbells instead of a barbell. 

4. Grasshopper pushup.
Like curls, pushups are renowned as an excellent exercise for building muscle and strength. This variation pays particular attention to your arms. To perform this exercise, get in a standard pushup position, but instead of having your palms open, use your fists to stabilize yourself.  The inside of your hands should be facing each other. Once in this position, you perform a pushup as usual by lowering your chest to the ground and pushing back up to start. If this hurts your fists, you can face your fingers out to work the same muscles. 

5. Supinated cable row. 
To perform this exercise, you will need a cable station. Use the low pulley on the cable station and attach a straight bar. Using an underhand grip, shoulder width apart, row the bar towards your belly button and return with control. Keep your hips back and your stance soft so that your torso is around 45 degrees angle to vertical. You can also do this with a barbell once you have mastered the exercise with the cable station.

prompt: I am moving to a new city and I don't know anyone here. I would like to make some new friends but I don't think I am confident enough to just go out and start talking to people. How can I make new friends?

messages.content: I am moving to a new city and I don't know anyone here. I would like to make some new friends but I don't think I am confident enough to just go out and start talking to people. How can I make new friends?

I understand starting in a new city can be a new challenge, but don't be discouraged here are some ideas to make new friends:

1. Social media: Social media is a great way to connect with new people in your area. For example, if there is a Reddit community for your new city, you can make a post there detailing a little bit about yourself, what you're interested in, and that you'd like to meet some new people. Of course, always exercise caution if and when you decide to meet up with anyone you have been talking to online.
2. Befriend colleagues: If you're starting a new job in the city, this is an easy way to meet new people and build friendships. If you have some colleagues that you click with, try asking them if they'd like to hang out outside of work and see how that goes.
3. Social events: Going to a large event is a great way to meet new people and maybe even develop friendships. For example, if you have a favorite music artist who is playing a show in your city, turn up a little early and try to strike up conversations with others waiting in line. Your shared love of the artist will already give you a common ground for building a friendship.
4. Take up a new hobby: Whether you have an existing hobby or want to take up a new one, it is a good way to meet new people who share your interests. Look online to see if there are any local groups or meet-ups for people who pursue the hobbies you enjoy.
5. Friendship apps: Apps aren't just for dating anymore! Many apps revolve around building new platonic friendships, such as Bumble BFF. You can make a profile listing your interests and hobbies and see who you connect with. As always, ensure if you're meeting someone from an app, do it in a safe and neutral environment.

Sounds exciting! I'd be happy to help you get prepared for your date:

1. Take a shower - Make sure you take a bath or shower before you go on your date. Don't go on a date immediately after work without getting clean and refreshed, as you may be carrying around sweat and grime from your job.
2. Get a haircut - Get unkempt hair under control. Cut your hair so it looks presentable, or if you elect to keep your hair long, at least put it in a ponytail or bun so it doesn't overhang your ears or get into your food when you're eating.
3. Groom your facial hair - If you have a beard or mustache, shave it off. If your date wants to get closer to you, you don't want your facial hair poking them or giving them a rash when you both get physically close and intimate. Or, if you insist on keeping your facial hair, at the very least, you should trim and groom it so it doesn't look scraggly.
4. Use fragrances (but don't overdo it!) - cologne or deodorant is always a plus...put some on before your date so you smell extra good. But don't overdo it, because an overwhelming smell of cologne can be too pungent for your date's nose and can put them off completely.
5. Dress to impress - Unless the occasion warrants it, don't come to a date with a t-shirt, surf shorts, and slippers/flip-flops. Dress nicely; this means wearing something that would be used on a date, like slacks or dress pants (or jeans), a button-up shirt or polo shirt, and closed-toe shoes.
6. Have transportation - If you don't have a mode of transportation, you can always get an Uber or taxi to take you to the location of the date. But try to secure some mode of transportation so you can easily travel to and from the date, or even take your date home when it's all over. For example, a bicycle would not be a good choice of transportation for two people.
7. Pick a nice place - Consider going on a date to a place that is fun and where both of you will enjoy being there, such as on a walk on the beach, to a nice restaurant or coffee shop, or to a movie at the theater. Places that are hectic or frenetic can be offputting to your date and can make conversation and getting to know them better near impossible (e.g. loud concerts, live fighting events, etc.)
8. Be polite - Be nice to your date; be a gentleman and mind your manners. Avoid using foul or abrasive language, be complimentary to your date, and show interest in the other person rather than focusing your conversation on yourself (unless your date asks you questions about yourself).
9. Refrain from using your phone - In this day and age of increased cell phone use, one of the best ways to show you are disinterested in your date is to use your phone while you are in their presence. Put the phone down, make eye contact with your date, and don't check calls or emails without at least asking permission from your date before doing so. Even then, try to keep the phone checking short and screen your calls so you aren't talking on the phone unless it is an emergency.

prompt: I'd like a list of houseplants that are easy to take care of. They must be plants that can take some degree of neglect. And they can be either small, tabletop plants or larger floor plants.

messages.content: I'd like a list of houseplants that are easy to take care of. They must be plants that can take some degree of neglect. And they can be either small, tabletop plants or larger floor plants.

• Pothos: This is a fast-growing plant with variegated leaves. The leaves can be left hanging or can be trained to grow upward as vines.

• Philodendron: This plant has deep green, heart-shaped leaves, is fast-growing, and does well in almost any light.

• Spider plant: This plant has variegated leaves and can make a great hanging plant. The plant will grow "mini" spider plants which can then be used to grow more full-sized plants. 

• Cactus: This plant needs lots of light, but can go for long periods without water. Therefore, it's great for warm, sunny rooms.

• African violet: This plant has fuzzy leaves and grows flowers of different colors depending on the plant variety. It can make a great tabletop plant.

• Peace Lily: This plant makes a great floor plant. It can grow in low light and will sprout white blooms in the spring.

- Steve's Prince of Steaks. This Northeast Philly cheesesteak spot hasn't changed its recipe much in the past forty years. If you want a classic steak sandwich made with rib-eye that's shaved to an eighth of an inch, then drenched in Cheese Whiz, look no further than Steve's Prince of Steaks.

messages.content: It hasn't rained in quite a while where I am, and my kids are starting to worry. So, to make this a little fun in some way, could you help me brainstorm two or three things we can do that is like an old wives tale from some culture or another to get rain? For example, the Native Americans would dance wearing feathers to represent wind and blue colors to represent rain. Meanwhile, in China, the shaman had to dance in a ring of fire until drops of sweat fell to the ground to water it. 
- Roman Ceremony - In some parts of Europe, there was a ceremony called: Calling the Waters. It involved the priest taking a sacred stone, making offerings to Jupiter, and then pouring water over the stone. 
- Old Wives' Tales - The Ozarks has numerous old wives' tales on how to get rain. Some of these that you can try include putting a dead snake belly-up on your fence, putting dead frogs in the road, or putting salt on gravel bars.

prompt: List three famous concepts that changed the world in statistics, mathematics and physics. Choose one example from each and go into detail about the concept or theorem and its impact.

messages.content: List three famous concepts that changed the world in statistics, mathematics and physics. Choose one example from each and go into detail about the concept or theorem and its impact.

Sure! I would be happy to go into detail about three famous concepts in statistics, mathematics, and physics!

1. The Invention of Calculus - Isaac Newton invented the concept of calculus in 1665. Although calculus has uses in physics, biology, economics, engineering, chemistry, and more, its most common association is with mathematics. Calculus is about studying the rate of change over time. Differential calculus can be compared to algebra. Calculus is used to define the slope of the curve, while algebra is more focused on straight lines. Integral calculus is used when the area under a graph needs to be calculated. It can break a sloped line into smaller segments to solve a problem that algebra can't.

Isaac Newton found that when trying to describe the speed of a falling object, the speed increased every second, although no mathematical solution explained why at the time. He found the explanation through calculus and used the same formula to explain the orbits of the sun, moon, and other planets. There are many uses for calculus today: it is heavily tied into all aspects of engineering, it can be used when data is being collected and analyzed, and, of course, it is still taught in various forms at the high school and, more typically, college level. Its invention also allowed for other scientific theories to come after it, such as the theory of relativity.

2. The Theory of Relativity - Widely known as the most famous theory in all of physics, the theory was invented by Albert Einstein. He had published a paper ten years earlier than his more famous theory about "special relativity," which explained space and time, but the theory did not address gravity. Einstein's theory expanded upon Newton's by determining the laws of physics are the same for all non-accelerating observers. He also showed the speed of light on its own is the same no matter what speed the observer is traveling. Equations for this theory also prove that massive objects distort spacetime. Light bends around massive objects like black holes, allowing it to act as a lens for things that are behind it; this is used by scientists to observe stars. Another aspect of the theory of relativity that is widely known is its direct impact on allowing the invention of the atomic bomb. Einstein was around during its creation but did not directly work on it himself, instead warning about the potential of its possible impact.

3. Normal Distribution - One of the most common concepts in statistics, also known as the Bell Curve, normal distribution affects many parts of our everyday lives. It explains various distributions such as the heights of the general public, errors in measurement, blood pressure, marks on a test, and intelligence of the populace, just to name a few examples. Related to the normal distribution is the standard deviation; the highest number of examples occur right in the middle of the graph, while standard deviations to the left and right are much less common. Typically two standard deviations away from the mean are rare, while three or more are exceedingly rare. This explains things like why there are so few extremely intelligent people. The probability of distribution means the odds of it happening are very unlikely, all factors considered.

prompt: Hi, I need 10 reasons why I should get a pet frog. I'm on the fence about it, but my best friend loves frogs and keeps trying to talk me into it. Thank you!

messages.content: Hi, I need 10 reasons why I should get a pet frog. I'm on the fence about it, but my best friend loves frogs and keeps trying to talk me into it. Thank you!

Frogs are incredible animals, and here are ten reasons why you should get one:

1. Frogs are relatively low-maintenance pets. Each species requires different care, so you should still research them heavily before you bring one into your living space, but they largely stay in their tanks and don't need you to walk or play with them like a dog or cat.
2. You can choose from hundreds of frog and toad species, each with unique traits. They have different songs, patterns, food and environment preferences, and levels of friendliness--yes, a frog can be friendly! Some are easier to care for than others as well.
3. Frogs delight you with their charming love songs. Look them up online, and see which one is your favorite. They have a range of different sounds: some croak, some bark, and some even make vibrating sounds.
4. You don't need a lot of space for a pet frog. If you live in an apartment, your landlord may permit a frog even if they don't let you have other types of pets. Just make sure that their tank is the right size for their species. They need plenty of room to climb and grow.
5. Frogs are affordable. You'll sink some money into your new pet, but they don't need vaccinations, large quantities of expensive food (usually), or other expenses associated with mammals.
6. If you don't have a pet store in your area, you can order frogs and toads online. This broadens your options because even pet stores carry a limited selection of species--if they carry frogs at all. You can even buy tropical varieties, such as red-eye tree frogs and poison dart frogs (captive varieties aren't poisonous.)
7. Frogs are important, but they're not a lifetime commitment. You should still do your research because some species can live for twenty years if you care for them correctly. However, your pet probably won't outlive you as some species might.
8. If you have kids, having a frog is a good way to teach them about responsibility and pet ownership without committing to a large mammal.
9. You can gently handle frogs and toads as long as you wash your hands first and wear rubber gloves.
10. Multiple frogs can live in the same tank if it's large enough--just do your research to make sure that you don't overcrowd them. Additionally, if you end up with male and female pairs, watch out for eggs! Frogs get frisky during mating season.

On a final note, make sure you buy frogs from a reputable pet store or breeder. Some kidnap them from other countries, causing many to die in transit, or breed them in unsafe conditions. Support people who treat frogs ethically. They're little lives, but they're just as important as any other creature.

prompt: I’m thinking about going to Zion national park next month. What are some of the best trails I can hike while there? I want to do really scenic ones with a great view. I’m okay with some variety. I plan to stay at the park for a few days and want some good options.

messages.content: I’m thinking about going to Zion national park next month. What are some of the best trails I can hike while there? I want to do really scenic ones with a great view. I’m okay with some variety. I plan to stay at the park for a few days and want some good options.

Zion is a world-famous park with tons of awesome trails! Here are a few of the best and some info on them.

- Canyon Overlook Trail: This is a great all-around hike in Zion. It’s fairly easy and quick and will take you to a viewpoint that overlooks Zion Canyon. It’s a view worth seeing if it’s your first time in the park.
- Angel's Landing: Angel's Landing has been touted as one of the best hikes in the world and will have you climbing a narrow ridge with the help of a chain to get to some stunning views. 
- The Narrows: The Narrows is another “best in the world” hike and has two options, going from the Bottom-Up or from the Top-Down. The bottom-up is more popular, having you walk for a few miles upriver before turning around. It will take you to wall street, an iconic section where the canyon narrows and the rocks above close in. The top-down is a 16-mile hike that takes you through all of the narrows. 
- West Rim trail: The west rim trail is another long hike through the length of the park and will reward you with various breathtaking views. This is the way to go if you want to experience as much of Zion as you can.
- Hidden Canyon: Hidden Canyon will take you a few hours to complete and will have you clung to the side of a cliff exploring a scenic canyon. If you want something that brings a sense of adventure and adrenaline this is the one for you.

prompt: I'm doing a project on ocean life and how much there is that we still don't know about it. As part of that, I'd like to mention a couple of underrated examples of things that live in the ocean. Please brainstorm for me a list of a handful of options I can choose from and explain how each is underrated.

messages.content: I'm doing a project on ocean life and how much there is that we still don't know about it. As part of that, I'd like to mention a couple of underrated examples of things that live in the ocean. Please brainstorm for me a list of a handful of options I can choose from and explain how each is underrated.

I'm happy to help with your project. Here are a few ideas that seem to fit what you are looking for: 

- Horseshoe Crabs - While some people have heard of this type of crab, fewer know how literally life-changing it is. For starters, they have milky-blue blood. This blood is used by the biomedical industry to test for contaminants on medical devices, and it has saved millions of lives by doing that. 
- Dinoflagellates - This tiny type of plankton lives all over the ocean and uses sunlight to make oxygen, which is very important to the ecosystem. They can also build up enough to make red tides, which are toxic and beautiful due to their bioluminescence. 
- Oysters - Though these might not seem underrated in that they are very popular to eat, there is a lot more to them. They can filter around 50 gallons of water a day, cleaning the ocean, and they also create reefs that other marine life needs. 
- Humphead Wrasse - These fish are fished far too much, and they have a couple of unique abilities that tend to be taken for granted. For starters, it can change its sex from female to male if it needs to. This type of wrasse can also eat some other marine life that is toxic to other things. 
- Xyloplax - This is a tiny type of starfish that lives entirely off the wood that finds its way into the ocean from floods and other things. This is necessary to break down this wood faster, yet few have ever heard of Xyloplax. 

I hope your project goes well!

messages.content: I’m looking to go to Amsterdam this summer but don’t know much about the city or its different neighborhoods. What are 5 neighborhoods and some things that they offer?

- De Pijp: De Pijp is a great place to stay for nightlife in Amsterdam. You can get to the heart of the city quickly via bike, and public transport can take you back to your lodging after a night out. 

- Centrum: Centrum is right in the city center. There are tons of places to stay, restaurants, and coffee shops, and all of the must-see places are nearby. You will have plenty to do while staying in Centrum.

- Oost: Oost is the best place for families to stay in Amsterdam. Oost is largely residential and has a Jewish heritage. There are tons of family-friendly attractions like the Verzetsmuseum, opera or ballet performances, and escape rooms.

- Oud West: Oud West is the best place to stay if you’re on a budget. You’ll be able to get a nice accommodation for fairly cheap, and the Van Gogh Museum isn’t too far. You can also enjoy a nice day at the Vondelpark.

- Jordaan: Jordaan has a village-like vibe, and its quiet atmosphere is perfect for couples visiting the city. There aren’t a whole lot of places to stay in Jordaan, but that’s part of what makes it such a great place to stay, there won’t be too many tourists.

messages.content: Suggest some hikes I can do in Norway. I am not as fit as I used to be so make sure they are no more than 5 or 6 miles long and not too difficult. I am also only there for a few days, so I only need three options.

Sure! Here are three appropriate hikes for you in Norway.

1. Pulpit Rock - otherwise known as Preikestolen, this is a very popular hike in Norway. While it is at the upper end of how far you would like to walk, it is considered easy to moderate in difficulty and has really amazing views. It is also easy to get to from the town of Stavanger, making it easily accessible.

2. Svolvaer Fløya and Svolvaergeita - this hike provides a great adventure in a short walk, allowing you the opportunity to simply hike up to the top of Fløya for one of the best views across all the islands or combine it with a rock climb up Svolvaergeita (otherwise known as The Goat).

3. Ryten and Kvalvika Beach - this hike in the Lofoten Islands involves a slightly strenuous hike to the top of a mountain, but is overall classed as easy to moderate. There is also a mini version of Trolltunga as part of the route, an area that is great for taking photos without the long hike to see the real thing.

prompt: I've found a lost dog, but I can't read the identification on their collar. What should I do?

messages.content: I've found a lost dog, but I can't read the identification on their collar. What should I do?

Here are some suggestions that may help with returning a lost dog. Make sure to look up local laws and regulations regarding lost animals before proceeding.

1. Contact the local relevant authorities: This is especially true if the dog is aggressive. You should not put yourself in harm's way to capture or restrain an aggressive animal. If there are specific guidelines in your area for the handling of lost or stray dogs, the relevant authorities, like animal control, should be able to inform you of them. 
2. Leave the dog with an animal shelter: If you are unable to take care of the dog for an extended period of time, it may be best to leave it at an animal shelter. It is best to research what resources, facilities, and services are available and willing in your area to accept the dog before you drop off the dog.
3. Post on social media: Social media groups that are local to your area might be able to spread awareness of a lost dog, and thus help you return it to its owner. Note that it remains important to take care with posting personal or private information online.
4. Ask neighbors in the area: It may be logical to surmise that the dog's owner is not too far from where you found the dog. Introducing yourself and the situation politely to neighbors in the area could result in a quick resolution.
5. Put up a flyer or poster: If you are able to take care of the dog for an extended period of time, you could put up a flyer or poster alerting people to the dog. It is important to include a description of the dog as well as a photo in order to help the owner identify that it is indeed their dog.
6. Check with a vet: Perhaps the dog is microchipped; it may be useful to contact a vet who may help with identifying the owner if the dog has indeed been chipped.

prompt: I want to create an amazing business card. Can you suggest to me some common mistakes you should avoid before creating business cards and explain how to avoid each?

messages.content: I want to create an amazing business card. Can you suggest to me some common mistakes you should avoid before creating business cards and explain how to avoid each?

Sure! A business card is your company’s identity. Here are some common mistakes you should avoid before creating business cards:

1.	Outdated Information: Don't give off a bad impression by having information on your card that is no longer accurate. Order new cards if necessary.

2.	Misprints and Typos: Grammatical errors and typos can make your business appear unprofessional. Always proofread your card before printing.

3.	Image Quality: High-resolution images are essential for clear printing. Avoid pixelated or blurry images that can detract from your card's design.

4.	Poor-Quality Card Stock: Selecting the appropriate card stock is critical. Using flimsy or low-quality paper can make your business appear cheap and unreliable.

5.	Unreadable Text or Tiny Print: A well-designed card shouldn't compromise readability. Avoid using hard-to-read fonts or tiny prints that make it difficult for customers to read your contact details.

6.	Focus on the Value: Your business card should communicate what problems you can solve and what value you provide to potential customers.

7.	Lack of Branding: Building brand recognition is key to differentiating yourself from competitors. Make sure your card reflects your branding elements, such as your color scheme and logo design.

8.	Visual Clutter: Avoid overwhelming your card with too many graphics, images, or text. Create enough white space to keep your designs clean and readable.

prompt: I am so sluggish and slow in the mornings – ugh! What are six ways that I can rev my brain and be more “awake” in the am?

messages.content: I am so sluggish and slow in the mornings – ugh! What are six ways that I can rev my brain and be more “awake” in the am?

Not everyone is an early bird, but many night owls still have AM responsibilities. Here are six ways to rev up your brain to feel more alert and attentive in the mornings when it’s hard to get out of bed! 

1. Take a cold shower with revitalizing scents to jolt your nervous system! 

Most people don’t want to get out of the warm embrace of their blankets, so a cold shower may take time to work up to. The cold water is an immediate wake-up call to your nervous system, but a lukewarm shower with revitalizing scents in shampoo and body wash can be just as effective. The best scents for alertness are spicy or have citrus notes, such as orange, cinnamon, rosemary, and peppermint. 

2. Avoid the allure of sugary cereals and other sweet breakfast foods. 

While it may be tempting to grab a doughnut and a Frappuccino on the way to work, resist the urge. Sweet breakfasts will increase your blood sugar, which can make you feel alert for a few hours before a hard crash of fatigue in the afternoon. 

Stick to a hearty, healthy breakfast with protein and heart-healthy fats instead. Eggs and bacon are a classic, but you could also blend a smoothie, have a slice of avocado toast, or opt for rolled oats with berries and a glass of whole milk. 

3. Drink a glass of ice-cold water before your morning cup of coffee. 

Many people can’t wait to have their cup of coffee in the mornings but steer clear until you’ve awakened your mind and body with a cold glass of water. Dehydration is a common cause of fatigue, so a glass of cold water will refresh your nervous system to get you moving in the AM. 

4. Listen to something upbeat, like a comedic, engaging podcast or your favorite “get up and go” music. 

Putting yourself in a good “go-getter” mood will help you awaken your senses in the mornings. Upbeat music or laughter are both great ways to help you feel more alert and prepped to take on the day. 

5. Stretch and work out fatigue with a quick walk outdoors. 

Not only will a good stretch and regular exercise help you sleep better, but a quick stroll outdoors in the morning is a change of scenery that tells your body and mind that it’s time to wake up for the day. Slow stretches work out kinks that accumulate in muscles while asleep.

6. Allow natural sunlight to permeate your surroundings in the mornings. 

This one may make you groan with dread, but sunshine suppresses melatonin production within your body. Melatonin is the chemical that makes you sleepy, and that’s encouraged in dark environments. Standing in sunlight for a few minutes after you wake up tells your mind and body that the day is getting started.

prompt: Can you recommend me some science fiction movies I might like? Don't include Star Wars.

messages.content: Can you recommend me some science fiction movies I might like? Don't include Star Wars.

Of course! Here are some science fiction movies for you to watch. I did not include Star Wars in the list.

• Interstellar (2014): In a future where Earth is dying, a team of astronauts are sent on a mission to find a new home for humanity. The team travels through a wormhole near Saturn and discovers several planets that could potentially support life. However, the planets are all located in different galaxies, and the astronauts must travel through space and time to reach them. The film explores themes of hope, love, and sacrifice, and it is a visually stunning and thought-provoking film that will stay with you long after you watch it.

• Arrival (2016): Twelve alien spacecraft appear in various locations around the world. The United States government sends a linguist to try to communicate with the aliens. The linguist, Louise Banks, quickly learns that the aliens communicate in a non-linear way and that their language is based on time. This makes it difficult for Louise to understand the aliens, but she eventually makes some progress. The film explores themes of language, time, and the nature of reality, and it is a beautiful and intelligent film that will stay with you long after you watch it.

• The Martian (2015): Astronaut Mark Watney is stranded on Mars after his crew is forced to evacuate the planet due to a severe dust storm. Watney must use his ingenuity and engineering skills to survive on Mars until a rescue mission can be launched. The film is a survival story, but it is also a story of hope and determination. It is a reminder that even in the most dire of circumstances, the human spirit can triumph.

• Blade Runner 2049 (2017): Thirty years after the events of the original Blade Runner, a new replicant (a bioengineered android) is tasked with hunting down a group of rogue replicants. The film is a visually stunning sequel that explores themes of identity, humanity, and the nature of reality. It is a dark and atmospheric film that will stay with you long after you watch it.

• Ex Machina (2014): Caleb Smith, a programmer at a large internet company, is selected to participate in a breakthrough experiment in artificial intelligence. Caleb is tasked with administering the Turing test to Ava, a humanoid robot that is designed to be as intelligent as a human being. However, Caleb soon begins to question whether Ava is as innocent as she seems. The film is a thought-provoking thriller that explores the nature of consciousness and the ethics of artificial intelligence.

prompt: Can you give me some relevant tax tips? I'm a self-employed person who lives in the US.

messages.content: Can you give me some relevant tax tips? I'm a self-employed person who lives in the US.

No problem. Here are some tax tips for a self-employed person living in the US:

1. Make Estimated Quarterly Payments: The IRS requires all self-employed individuals in the US to make estimated quarterly payments for the tax they will owe at the end of the year. Doing this can help save on fines and penalties.
2. Save More Than Needed: Since it's almost impossible to estimate the exact amount of tax you will owe, it's always a good idea to put aside a little more than you think you might need. That way, if you do owe more, it won't be a problem, and if you end up getting some money back, it will be a nice surprise for your savings.
3. Keep Track of Expenses: The IRS allows you to write off business expenses, so make sure you keep track. Although they don't ask for evidence when submitting, they may if you're ever audited, so having receipts is a good idea. Some people keep a separate credit card and put all business expenses on that to make them easy to track.
4. Get a Professional Tax Preparer: Tax laws can be complicated, especially if you're self-employed. Getting a professional tax preparer can ensure you receive all of the refunds and credits you're entitled to, so you don't pay more than you have to.
5. Never Lie or Exaggerate: It's crucial to make sure you understand the IRS's rules and follow them. While they are generally forgiving of mistakes, tax evasion and avoidance are serious crimes.

Since everyone's tax situation is different, make sure you do your research and consider the advice of a financial expert, as they'll know what the best things to do in your situation are and how to save you the most money.

prompt: Can you help me put together a list of all the home consoles Nintendo made before the Wii? I'd like them to be ordered by year starting with the earliest. Also, I don't want handhelds. Please only give me home console options.

messages.content: Can you help me put together a list of all the home consoles Nintendo made before the Wii? I'd like them to be ordered by year starting with the earliest. Also, I don't want handhelds. Please only give me home console options.

Got it! Here is a list of all the home consoles Nintendo developed before the Wii, listed by year.

1. NES - The NES came out in America in 1985, and it helped the North American video game market recover from its crash in 1983. This console was a place to play 8-bit titles, and it was the best-selling gaming console of its time. Originally, the NES was marketed as Famicom in Japan, but it was renamed to the NES when it came to America. When it came out, there was a $99 option that came with Super Mario Bros. There was also a $199.99 deluxe set that came with accessories and two games.
2. SNES - Nintendo followed up the NES with the SNES in 1990. This makes it the second home console developed by Nintendo, and it was also a huge success. When it was released, it had to compete with Sega's Mega Drive. That being said, the Nintendo titles played a role in making it the best-selling console of its time. There were different versions, and cartridges couldn't be played on consoles that came from another country. The SNES was called the Super Famicom in Japan.
3. Virtual Boy - The Virtual Boy came out in 1995, and it was a torchlight in virtual reality. That being said, it was a disaster in terms of its release. This console could be placed on a surface, and players could see it by leaning forward into the visor. This made some players feel sick to their stomachs, and it had a very short lifespan.
4. Nintendo 64 - The Nintendo 64 came out in 1996, and it utilized a 64-bit CPU, making it truly powerful for its time. The Nintendo 64 was less popular than previous consoles, and this was in part due to the competition from Sony and Sega. Today, it's still known as an amazing console.
5. Nintendo GameCube - The GameCube came out in 2001, and it was the first Nintendo console to use optical discs. It also allowed players to save their games through the use of memory cards that went up to 64 MB. The Gamecube came by at a time with a lot of competition. Competitors included Sony, Microsoft, and Sega. It had lots of initial success but didn't sell many consoles in the long run. The Gamecube is historical and iconic, but it was considered a flop in its time.

2. Water, oil, and baking powder: Use 2 tablespoons flat water, 2 teaspoons baking powder, and 1 teaspoon vegetable oil to equal 1 large egg.

4. Applesauce: Use 1/4 cup unsweetened apple sauce to equal 1 large egg.
5. Buttermilk: Use 1/4 cup buttermilk to equal 1 large egg.

4. Overnight cinnamon rolls can be mixed and proofed the day before in the pan you’ll use to make them. Icing can be store-bought or premade as well. That morning all you’ll have to do is toss them in the oven.

5. A quiche can be baked off the night before and reheated that morning. Quiches are a fairly simple process of pouring an egg and vegetable mixture into a crust - and store-bought crust is just fine!

prompt: I've been accoladed at my school for my ability to write, and I've also just started looking into blogging as a job. Recently, I learned about SEO and want to know more about how I should implement it. Can you walk me through 5 important rules for SEO writing in the form of a list?

messages.content: I've been accoladed at my school for my ability to write, and I've also just started looking into blogging as a job. Recently, I learned about SEO and want to know more about how I should implement it. Can you walk me through 5 important rules for SEO writing in the form of a list?

Here are those SEO writing tips for you:

1. Write for people - An important factor in SEO is backlinks. These are essentially links to your website from other websites. That means that you want to make the content focused on humans. If there are too many keywords or it sounds robotic, it won't have as much of an opportunity to be shared.
2. Understand the algorithm - Google updates its algorithm frequently, so it's important to be up to date in your knowledge of the algorithm. This also goes for any other search engine you are trying to share your content through. What Google looks for is webpages with the best quality, and they make their updates to make sure their search engine is effective.
3. Find and use keywords - To make an SEO-optimized blog, you need to do some keyword research. You want a main keyword, which may have too much competition in search. So, when you choose keywords, you should look for keywords that aren't searched as often. If they aren't searched as much, they will have less competition. It also helps to find words to go along with your keywords. Doing so tells search engines that your content actually is about the topic it says it's about. 
4. Link out to quality sites - Using links shares where your information comes from, and your information should come from high-quality sites. Search engines want helpful information to be easily available, and linking out to good sites tells these engines that you use good sources.
5. Use Subheadings -  You can also use subheadings that include keywords. These break the text up into smaller portions which makes it easier to read through. Using keywords in subheadings also puts them in a more prominent spot than in the text.

prompt: I'd like to save the flowers from my wedding and I want them to stay looking nice. Give me some ideas for how to preserve them.

messages.content: I'd like to save the flowers from my wedding and I want them to stay looking nice. Give me some ideas for how to preserve them.

Here are a few methods of preserving flowers that may work for your wedding flowers:

1. Press them - Gather heavy flat objects such as large books or garden pavers, and wax paper. Arrange a few flowers, or even an entire bouquet, onto the wax paper, cover them with another sheet of wax paper, and press this between the heavy objects. Leave them sitting for about 7 to 10 days.

2. Hang them - Turn your flowers upside down and hang them in a dry location for about a week. Once they're dry, you can turn them back over and arrange them into a vase.

3. Silica gel - Silica gel can be found in craft stores and is a type of sand that is very drying. Submerging your flowers in silica will cause them to dry out and still look very much like they did when they were fresh.

4. Resin - You can either buy the supplies yourself or have someone do this for you - arrange the flowers you would like to preserve in a mold, then pour clear resin to encase them. This can be made into a paperweight or just a decoration.

2. Arc de Triomphe: Built in 1836, the Arc de Triomphe is a monument in Paris dedicated to those who fought and died in both the Napoleonic Wars and the French Revolution.  The names of all the French victories and generals in the wars are inscribed on the inner and outer surfaces. It also contains the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier beneath it.

prompt: I always see police officers using a belt with lots of gadgets on it. Can you please give me a rundown of what those gadgets are, and what they are used for?

messages.content: I always see police officers using a belt with lots of gadgets on it. Can you please give me a rundown of what those gadgets are, and what they are used for?

Depending on the jurisdiction and country, a uniformed police officer usually wears a utility belt that carries the following equipment:

1. Duty firearm - Police officers are armed with a handgun or pistol; the type depends on the jurisdiction or area of work. A typical standard-issue police firearm in the United States is a semi-automatic pistol, usually a 9-millimeter caliber, Glock handgun. The Glock handgun has a polymer frame and metal slide and has at least a 10-round capacity, but usually is capable of 15 to 17 rounds.
2. Handcuffs - Metal handcuffs are needed to physically restrain individuals during an investigation. Handcuffs are circular metal bracelets attached by a metal-linked chain; they can be double-locked to ensure they do not tighten on an arrestee's wrists or injure them during their transport to a lockup facility.
3. OC spray - Oleoresin capsicum (the active ingredient in pepper spray) is made from the oily residue of hot peppers, which is placed into a canister and made to propel in either a spray (using an alcohol- or water-based suspension fluid) or a foam, which prevents inadvertent spraying of surrounding people.
4. ECW - Also colloquially known as a "Taser," the Electronic Controlled Weapon (ECW) is a plastic-framed pistol-type weapon that is capable of launching twin darts attached to the weapon by wires that become energized by 50,000 volts of electricity powered by a battery pack located in the grip of the gun. An ECW is used to control a violently resisting individual by achieving neuromuscular incapacitation (NMI).
5. Baton - A police baton can be either of the wooden straight-stick variety or a metal collapsible baton. Both batons can be carried at once and each one has its benefits.
6. Gloves - Latex gloves are a must in the field, especially when officers are handling contaminated items or touching people who may have communicable diseases. Several pairs of latex gloves can be rolled up tightly and kept in a glove pouch on the officer's utility belt.
7. Magazines - An officer may carry one or more extra magazines for their duty firearm in pouches on their utility belt in case they need it.

prompt: My car is old and I'll need to replace it soon. What options should I look at?

messages.content: My car is old and I'll need to replace it soon. What options should I look at?

Buying a new car is an exciting time, but it also requires careful consideration because you will likely have that car for several years. You should think about your lifestyle and what you expect from a car before deciding what to buy. When buying a car, another important consideration is the type of fuel, so consider whether you want petrol, diesel, or possibly a hybrid or electric car.
There are many types of cars to choose from, and here are some of the most popular types:

1. Sedan
A sedan is a very practical car if you need it to transport more than two people. It has a 4-door design and comes in a range of sizes, so it's easy to find something you like.

2. Coupe
A coupe is a 2-door car that can have a more attractive look. It's a good option if you don't often transport more than 2 people, but it can be less practical if you regularly have more passengers, as there is less room in the back.

3. Sports car
A sports car is a good choice if you're looking for great performance and aerodynamic styling. A sports car will have a smaller interior space and a small boot capacity, so it's not a very practical car. It is also more expensive to maintain due to its high fuel consumption.

4. A convertible
A convertible car is similar to a coupe but with a removable top. It's a great option for summer driving but not so practical in winter, and the boot space is very limited.

5. SUV
SUVs are popular for anyone who wants a car with off-road capabilities but still wants a more stylish look compared to a pickup truck. SUVs can fit more people and lots of cargo, but they are not very fuel-efficient.

prompt: Can you give me some suggestions on how writers can organize their ideas for their content?

messages.content: Can you give me some suggestions on how writers can organize their ideas for their content?

Here are five ways a writer can organize their thoughts to create content that is easy to understand. 

1. Chronological Order 
Chronological order is a way to organize ideas as a storyteller or writer. It involves dishing out ideas in the precise order of time from first to last. This type of order is used most often in expository writing or narratives that inform or explain something. It is particularly useful when describing an event or a series of events. 

Consider when you were younger, and you were trying to explain to the principal why you shouldn't be placed in detention. You had to describe the events that led to that problem carefully and in order so that they would understand your point of view. When writing, you do the same thing when you need to help your reader navigate the process and understand the context of the narrative. Some transition words to use when writing in chronological order include first, then, next, last, and finally. 

2. Logical Order 
Logical order is precisely what it sounds like. The framework is used to avoid any confusion for the reader. You will need to organize your ideas in this framework if your reader requires a good understanding at one point before you can move on to the next point. 

Before a teacher talks to their students about Robert Frost's poem The Road Not Taken, for instance, they would need to give an example of what it's like to make a big or difficult decision. That way, the listener or reader will understand the true nature of the poem when they hear it. Some good transitional words or phrases to use for this order include: First, you should understand; keep that in mind while I explain; remember when I said; etc. 

3. Climactic Order 
With this order, you keep the most important part until the very end of the story or piece. You should use it when you want to build up excitement such as in a suspense story, or when writing a list ranking items from worst to best. You want the final point to resonate with your reader and, therefore, save it for the very end. Some transitional phrases to use with this order include: first of all, more importantly, just as importantly, and finally. 

4. Random Order 
This order allows you to put your ideas out there on a whim without any specific or logical reasoning behind them. You can organize your ideas this way when your points all have equal value of importance or they can sit independently with one another in understanding. You will want to use association ideas between points to transition from one thought to the next instead of using transition terms or phrases. 

5. Spatial Order 
With this order, you describe a scene as things are arranged in their physical space by moving from one detail to the next or as viewed from one stationary vantage point. This order is used whenever you want your readers to visualize the space or if you want to improve a scene by causing the reader to use all their senses. Use this arrangement when you want to organize the ideas you are describing in your workspace, like a product use or a place description. It is a great way to slow down a story when it is getting too intense or if you want to pace yourself before revealing a surprise. Add in a few point-of-view descriptions of the setting at the moment. Some transition words to use for this order include, just to the left or right, behind, between, across from, arising out of, etc.

prompt: How can I protect my skin from sunshine in the summertime? I love being outdoors, especially at beaches, but I always wind up looking like a lobster, haha. Help!

messages.content: How can I protect my skin from sunshine in the summertime? I love being outdoors, especially at beaches, but I always wind up looking like a lobster, haha. Help!

Great job on knowing the importance of skin protection to prevent damage from the sun! 
Here are a few tips on how to shield yourself from the summertime sunshine while enjoying time outdoors. 

•	Read the directions for your sunscreen and thoroughly follow those directions! 

Sunscreen is formulated and tested rigorously and with rigid guidelines. Your sunscreen should be broad-spectrum protection with an SPF of 15 or greater. For the best results, if you don’t get into the water, reapply every 2 hours. However, if you get into water or sweat excessively, slather a new layer on as directed on the bottle, which is usually every 30 to 45 minutes. 

•	Eat a nutritious diet to naturally protect skin cells against sun damage. 

Some foods are packed with antioxidants specifically to prevent skin cell damage and encourage fortified protection from UV rays. While food doesn’t do all the work when it comes to the prevention of sun damage, you need foods that are rich in vitamin C, vitamin E, niacin, folate, omega-3 fats, and carotenoids. 

-  These fruits and vegetables and packed with vitamin C -  oranges and grapefruits, red peppers, broccoli, and tomatoes. 
-  Wheat germ oil, almonds, and sunflower seeds are great sources of Vitamin E
-  Carotenoids are needed to help keep your skin and eyes healthy. Some carotenoic-rich foods are bell peppers, cantaloupe, mangoes, and sweet potatoes.
-  Foods high in niacin are chicken breast, salmon, brown rice, and peanuts. 
-  Folate-rich foods include beef, liver, spinach, and Brussels sprouts.
-  Foods that are full of Omega-3 are fish, especially salmon and sardines, flax and flaxseed oil, walnuts, and canola oil. 

•	Avoid “peak times” for summer sunshine. 

The sunshine is typically the hottest and brightest between 10 am and 2 pm, depending on where you live. To avoid the most intensive UV rays, try to stay indoors or in the shade between those hours. 

Other things to remember about skin protection and sun damage: 

- There’s no such thing as waterproof sunscreen! Water resistance is based on spectrum, brand, and SPF, but no sunscreen can be completely waterproof. Every sunscreen has re-appliance directions based on how much you swim or sweat while outdoors. 

- Umbrellas can lend protection from sun damage. Headed to the beach? Take a large umbrella with you to sit under when you aren’t cruising the shoreline or playing in the waves. You’ll get to enjoy the sand and the surf without the direct effects of UV rays on your skin. 

- Sunscreen and precautions against sun damage are important every day, even on cloudy days, especially when the sunshine is strongest, brightest, and hottest in the summer months. The sun’s UV rays can penetrate clouds, resulting in burns, even though they may not be as severe or appear as quickly as they would on clear days.

prompt: How about a list of only history museums in Portland, Or?

messages.content: How about a list of only history museums in Portland, Or?

1. Pittock Mansion: This historic mansion was built in 1909 for Henry Pittock, a prominent Portland businessman and newspaper publisher. Today, the mansion is a museum that offers visitors a glimpse into the history of Portland and the life of the Pittock family. The mansion's grounds also offer stunning views of the city.
2. Oregon Historical Society Museum: The Oregon Historical Society Museum is dedicated to preserving and sharing the history of Oregon and the Pacific Northwest. The museum's exhibits cover a range of topics, from the Native American tribes that lived in the region before European settlement to the pioneers who traveled the Oregon Trail.
3. The Oregon Rail Heritage Center: This museum is dedicated to preserving and sharing the history of rail transportation in Oregon. The center's collection includes three historic steam locomotives, as well as other artifacts and exhibits related to rail travel.
4. World Forestry Center Discovery Museum: The World Forestry Center Discovery Museum explores the history, science, and culture of forestry. Exhibits include interactive displays about tree biology, sustainable forestry practices, and the role of forests in mitigating climate change.
5. The USS Blueback Submarine: This decommissioned submarine is now a museum that offers visitors the chance to explore the inner workings of a real submarine. The museum includes exhibits about the history of the Blueback and the role of submarines in the U.S. Navy.

Naxos also has 41 beautiful villages, each with its own individual culture and impressive centuries-old architecture. Furthermore, it is home to the "Portara," a 2,500-year-old doorway that "does not lead anywhere" but was once the centerpiece of the Greek god Apollo temple.
2. Aegina: Aegina is the closest island to Athens and home to unique monuments, history, and culture. Relax on one of Aegina's amazing beaches and splurge on fresh fish and delicious pistachios.
3. Kythira: One of the main attractions of Kythira is hiking to the Venetian Castle of Chora, which was built in 1503. Visitors can also explore the Cave of Agia Sofia, where inside the stone cave is a chapel dedicated to Agia Sophia. Kythira is also home to numerous waterfalls that are great for swimming.

prompt: Recently it feels like my parents have been smothering me even though I'm in my 20s, but I'm awful at setting boundaries. Can you give me a list of a few tips I can use to set boundaries with my parents? Include a tip that can help me communicate more clearly with them.

messages.content: Recently it feels like my parents have been smothering me even though I'm in my 20s, but I'm awful at setting boundaries. Can you give me a list of a few tips I can use to set boundaries with my parents? Include a tip that can help me communicate more clearly with them.

I can definitely do that. Here's your list going through tips for setting boundaries with your parents.

1. Set boundaries with gratitude and appreciation - It isn't disrespectful to set boundaries, but you should still set them, and your parents should respect them. You can set boundaries and avoid possible hurt feelings by wording what you say carefully and sharing that you appreciate them,
2. Be direct - It can be hard to get your parents to recognize that you're independent. This especially goes if you have moved back in with them. You can try to evade possible conflict by not saying anything, But, it's better to share your concerns rather than conceal them.
3. Be clear - Being vague also doesn't help. When you set boundaries, you should be clear with your parents. This makes sure that they understand exactly what you mean. If they aren't getting it you can give them examples of things they've done that have upset you and tell them other things they can do instead.
4. Compromise - Stating your boundaries can gently remind your parents that you make your own choices. If your boundaries aren't working for them, you should find some sort of compromise. If your parents ask inappropriate questions about your relationships, you can let them know it's okay to chat about your relationships but not go into a territory that's uncomfortable for you. When you find a middle ground, it can make everyone more satisfied with the outcome.

prompt: Give me a list of 5 lesbian movies from the 90s

messages.content: Give me a list of 5 lesbian movies from the 90s

Here's a list of 5 lesbian movies from the 1990s:

1. "Bound" (1996) is a sapphic film directed by the Wachowski sisters, featuring Gina Gershon and Jennifer Tilly as a pair of lovers planning a heist. It is a stylish neo-noir movie with Susie Bright, a queer sex educator, choreographing the sex scenes between the two main characters.
2. "The Incredibly True Adventure of Two Girls in Love" (1995) isn't just about coming out or facing homophobia, though both are part of the movie. It is an endearing and honest portrayal of two teenage girls falling in love.
3. "Go Fish" (1994) is a romantic comedy about a college student named Max who goes on a date with a woman named Ely. Although they have chemistry, they part ways after the date. The film was co-written by Guinevere Turner and directed by Rose Troche, who broke up during production.
4. "But I'm a Cheerleader" (1999) is a must-see lesbian film directed by Jamie Babbit. The movie follows 17-year-old cheerleader Megan (Natasha Lyonne), who is sent to a conversion therapy camp called True Directions by her conservative family after they suspect she might be gay. Megan gradually realizes her true sexual identity as she falls for fellow camper Graham (Clea DuVall) and wonders whether it's all that bad to be lesbian.
5. "The Watermelon Woman" (1996) is a romantic dramedy about a Black video store clerk named Cheryl who decides to make a documentary about a Black "mammy" actress known only as "The Watermelon Woman." The film follows Cheryl as she tracks down the actress and explores her own romantic relationship with a customer at the video store named Diana. Directed by Cheryl Dunye, the film is considered a touchstone of the New Queer Cinema movement and was the first feature film directed by an out Black lesbian.

prompt: Trying to put together a week's worth of activities for the kids I'm babysitting this summer. They should be indoor activities that don't include screen time. Their ages are 5, 8, and 10

messages.content: Trying to put together a week's worth of activities for the kids I'm babysitting this summer. They should be indoor activities that don't include screen time. Their ages are 5, 8, and 10

Alright, check out these indoor, screen-free ideas for kids: 

ARTS & CRAFTS
Arts and crafts are great for keeping little hands busy and screen-free, and they can be tailored to what you have on hand and what works best for you and the kids. For example, you could place a mirror in front of the child and have them draw their own self-portrait. You could also incorporate something like origami or collage-making from old magazines. 

PLAY A GAME
A classic time filler game that is indoors - Hide and Seek! Make sure to clarify rules and boundaries before gameplay begins. Simon Says is another good option for an indoor game. 

PLAY A CARD OR BOARD GAME
There are dozens of card and board games to choose from. CandyLand, Sorry, and Operation are a few classic board games. You could also play a card game like UNO, Old Maid, or Go-Fish. 

PUT ON A SHOW
You could put on a puppet show with the kids or have them perform one for you. If you don't have puppets, you could use stuffed animals or make your own by decorating paper lunch bags or drawing the puppet on paper and gluing it to a popsicle stick. Another show option is acting out a book. 

STORYTIME
Don't forget storytime! Reading to the children and having them read to you are good options for a calm indoor activity away from screens. 

BUILD A FORT
Gather blankets, pillows, and cushions and work together to construct a fort. This lends itself to pretend-play adventures as well as providing a cozy place to read books. 

DANCE PARTY
If the kids have some energy to burn or just love to dance, try an indoor dance party.

Although dogs can be a handful and they can take a fair amount of time to train, there's no doubt that they're loyal and wonderful companions. Golden retrievers and poodles are good breeds for first-time owners as they're generally easy to take care of.

2. Cats: A beloved icon of the pet world, cats are known to be quite independent and extroverted as they can easily stroll around the neighborhood and find their way back to you. Take note that cats use litter boxes so you have to clean up after them regularly.

3. Hamsters: If you're looking for something small and manageable, hamsters are the perfect pet choice for you. They're usually harmless and easy to maintain with no risk of aggressive behavior or unhealthy habits.

4. Rats: Although rats can be intimidating for most people, they make great pets as long as you treat them gently and carefully. They do have some defense mechanisms that you'll have to get used to, but they're generally pretty calm and friendly creatures that you can easily get along with.

5. Fish: Fish can make great pets as long as you maintain a safe boundary for them. Their tank or aquarium should be well-built, regularly cleaned, and placed at a suitable location where it doesn't easily fall over. 

Overall, owning a pet is a great way to showcase your passion for nature and wildlife, while giving you a fulfilling sense of attachment and responsibility. It's best to explore your options and determine what kind of pet would be best suitable for your house.

prompt: What are some things to tell a flat earther to convince them the earth is round?

messages.content: What are some things to tell a flat earther to convince them the earth is round?

Here are some arguments you can use to prove that the Earth is round.

• The Earth's shadow on the moon during a lunar eclipse is round. If the Earth were flat, its shadow on the moon would be a straight line.

• Different constellations are visible in the night sky from different parts of the world. This is only possible if the Earth is a sphere.

• When ships sail over the horizon, they do not simply shrink until they are out of sight. Instead, they slowly disappear hull first, which is only possible if the Earth curves away from the observer.

• The Earth's gravity pulls equally from all sides. This would not be possible if the Earth were flat.

• There are thousands of photographs and videos of the Earth from space that show it is a sphere. These images have been taken by astronauts, satellites, and even weather balloons.

prompt: Gaming is one of the most popular forms of entertainment in the world. With a massive surge in gamers in recent years due to the pandemic, there is a high demand for gaming content. Can you give me 5 tips for new gamers? These tips should be basic, nothing advanced. Also, be sure to include at least two tips about aiming.

messages.content: Gaming is one of the most popular forms of entertainment in the world. With a massive surge in gamers in recent years due to the pandemic, there is a high demand for gaming content. Can you give me 5 tips for new gamers? These tips should be basic, nothing advanced. Also, be sure to include at least two tips about aiming.

Sure! Here are five tips for new gamers:

1) Train hand-eye coordination. How quickly you react to events in video games depends on your hand-eye coordination. Hand-eye or eye-hand coordination refers to your eyes and hands working simultaneously to solve your situation. You can improve your hand-eye coordination by playing sports, playing more video games, practicing juggling, playing cornhole, painting, or any activity requiring you to use your hands and eyes simultaneously.
2) Practice your aim. Aiming is a big part of most games. FPS games are extremely popular, and they rely heavily on aiming. You can practice aiming by playing custom games against AIs, using practice ranges, and changing your settings to match your play style better.
3) Fix your crosshair. Everyone has a different play style. To understand yours better, try experimenting with the crosshair you use. Changing your crosshair will improve your aim and help you become a better gamer.
4) Learn more about the game. Whatever games you're playing, you need to understand them. You cannot improve at the game if you don't know why certain actions are good or bad. For example, if you died, analyze why you died. Was it bad positioning? Were you not listening closely enough? You'll become a better gamer by analyzing the game and learning more about the ins and outs of it,
5) Discover your strengths and weaknesses. Every gamer has strengths and weaknesses, no matter what game they're playing. Some players are naturally gifted at aiming, while others are not. Some gamers are gifted with game sense, while others are not. Determine what your strengths and weaknesses are, and work on your weaknesses. If you can, try working on your weaknesses in an area where you're strong. For example, if you have good positioning but a bad aim, try improving your aim by positioning yourself in an area you feel more comfortable practicing your aim.

prompt: I need five ideas on how to make my bedroom more relaxing and cozier. Better sleep and a calmer mind is the end goal!

messages.content: I need five ideas on how to make my bedroom more relaxing and cozier. Better sleep and a calmer mind is the end goal!

Your bedroom should be a place where you feel safe and comfortable from the moment you step foot in it. You should long for the sanctuary of your bedroom in the evenings, especially after a long workday has left you feeling stressed and haggard. 

Did you know that there are 335 million people in the United States and one-third of them aren’t getting enough sleep? While there are many contributing factors to the lack of good doze, one main component is the lack of a properly relaxing and cozy space. 

For a calmer mind and better sleep, here are five ideas for making your bedroom a more relaxing and cozier safe place. 

1. Choose colors that remind you of calmness and peace. 

For many people, various shades of blue or purple are calming colors. Cerulean blue, for instance, is a favorite because it reminds most people of the oceans. Whereas, purple is often symbolic of luxury, which many people associate with a plush and cozy bedroom environment. 

However, color therapy is different for everyone, and the trick is finding colors that are soothing and calming specifically to you. It can be any color that evokes a peaceful brain response. While you don’t have to flood your bedroom with that singular color, a few splashes in pillows, blankets, and even on the walls could have a safe, comforting effect on your brain and body. 

2. What’s your “perfect storm” for a good night’s sleep? 

As everyone’s calm colors are different, so are everyone’s ideas of an ideal sleep space. While some people love complete darkness and a cold bedroom with a fan on high throughout the year, others are happier and sleep better with a nightlight in a quiet room of warm, still air. It’s a personal preference, often associated with the ways you slept growing up. Ergo, it could be a catalyst for better sleep and a calmer mind as an adult too. 

It may take trial and error, but work on discovering the environment that is most conducive to your calm state of mind and a good night’s rest. Once you’ve found your “perfect storm” of peace, it should be easier to create a cozy, calm environment in the bedroom. 

3. Bring nature into the bedroom with crystals, a vase of flowers, or windowsill succulents. 

Nature is balance, and finding balance in your bedroom could mean reminding yourself of the equilibrium found in nature. For instance, you could add greenery with windowsill succulents, or bring a bloom of color onto your nightstand with a fresh vase of flowers. 

Into the mystical side of nature? Crystals are symbolic of inner feelings and your psyche, so invest and display crystals that represent what you want. For instance, black tourmaline repels negative energies, while amethyst encourages good dreams and deeper sleep. 

4. Engage your senses with softness and soothing scents. 

Calmness and peace are felt across all of your senses, so engage in those before bedtime. You could, for example, invest in a sound machine for the gentle lull of ocean waves or a cacophony of cicadas and crickets to remind you of your childhood. You could also surround yourself with softness, like plush pillows and luxurious blankets atop crisp, clean sheets. 

Another way to invite calm into your bedroom is with the right scents. Lavender is naturally soothing to the mind, while vanilla is a subtle, mellow fragrance that transports your brain back to simpler, peaceful times. 

You don’t have to douse your pillows and blankets but use a room spritz to liven the air or do the same with a candle. Just don’t forget to blow out the candle before you doze off. 

5. The less clutter in your bedroom, the less clutter in your mind before bedtime. 

Clutter of your safe space is clutter of your mind because when the clutter becomes too much, your brain will latch onto the worry and responsibility of eventually having to clean and organize everything cluttered. It’s a thought that can keep you awake at night! 

Use your day to declutter and organize your bedroom. The less worry you give yourself, the better sleep you’ll have, and the calmer your mind will be. Remember that the aim here is to create a haven for yourself.

prompt: Hello, I'm having some difficulty figuring out how to write a comic book and would like some information, such as where to start, what media I should use, and all the steps needed to create a comic book.

messages.content: Hello, I'm having some difficulty figuring out how to write a comic book and would like some information, such as where to start, what media I should use, and all the steps needed to create a comic book.

Certainly! Creating a comic book can be a difficult but rewarding venture. Here are some things to consider when creating a new comic book:

1. Protagonist/Antagonist - Who is the main character/villain of the story? Your characters can be anything you want them to be; they don't necessarily have to follow the tradition of being individuals with superpowers. For instance, you could create characters who are based on people like yourself, living an ordinary life and dealing with ordinary, relatable problems. Consider the works of Harvey Pekar ("American Splendor"), which showcase stories about ordinary people. Or, if you decide to write characters who follow the fantasy superhero trope, know who they are (origin, superpowers, and how they got them, etc.). Generally, your characters should be fleshed out completely.
2. Story - A good story can be made from any situation, but generally, most stories follow a formula that has been used in storytelling for centuries (i.e., Man vs. Man, Man vs. Environment). You could also write an autobiographical story or a story about other people who have lived or are still living. Your story is as creative and compelling as you make it, and it does not have to adhere to any set rules as long as it tells a coherent story that is worth reading.
3. Illustrations - Drawing comic book characters and scenery can be done by yourself by hand or digitally using programs found online. You can also hire someone to draw the comic books for you if you have no desire or artistic skill to do it on your own. When making the illustrations for your comic book, have a clear idea of what you want the drawings to convey and consider using drawing techniques that show actions taking place (e.g., using "action lines" to illustrate a person's punch wooshing by another person's face.)
4. Format - You can decide to have either a printed comic book on paper or a digital comic book that can be distributed via email or an app. With either option, you will still adhere to the same aforementioned steps, but the approach to going through these steps may differ slightly. For instance, making a digital comic book will still require illustrations, but illustrating digital comics will require the use of programs (i.e., Adobe, Paint, et al.) whereas printed comic books require ink and paper. Also, printing a comic book will result in something you can hold with your own hands but can become torn or worn over time, whereas a digital comic book has no tactile feel to it but will never deteriorate.
